It's been driving us crazy and I don't see any mention of alternate endings anywhere in the IMDb information.

reviews.review_title: Gorgeously shot bleak and twisty midwinter thriller
reviews.content: If, like me, there is nothing you like better then curling up on the couch with the fire burning and watch other people struggling in the sleet and snow then this is for you. It has deservedly won multiple awards for cinematography and it is visually absolutely breathtaking. Although initially somewhat formulaic with the missing daughter the plot is not predictable, the script is tight and the acting is subtle. Very entertaining if this sort of thing is your cup of tea.

I saw this movie Monday night, .............................Excellent story line...............................Every character s gives superb performance..Who's that .? question will rotate around into mind,you'll only guess ,may be this one But finally you 'll get the answer in last sequence..Sometime you'll get few emotional moment for characters ...You won't leave the chair until complete the movie ..........................Good things=casting, storyline, superb performance .......................Badthing=149 min(2.29) long........................My rating I is 8 out of 10..I must recommend.... to watch it

reviews.review_title: I felt uneasy the whole time
reviews.content: Admittedly, I hadn't read the synopsis before watching this film, so I thought it was a coming of age drama starring Jackman and Minette. It was a genuinely terrifying surprise. My heart dropped through my entire body and my mouth went dry. That was my state for most of the movie. Prisoners is a justifiably unsettling film. It does a great job of building tension and keeping the stakes high right until the very end. I had so many different emotions while watching, most of them resulting in tears. It was so hard to watch, but impossible for me to tear myself away.The writing is near perfect, and the performances by each actor really has you second guessing who the bad guy really is. Every word of dialogue could be a lie, or it could be the most pertinent information of the whole case. The ending few scenes had so many "aha!" Moments that my mind was blown.A brilliant thing about this movie, and my favourite element of a good crime drama, is that all of the clues are there for you to follow along. We see everything that Jake Gyllenhaal's detective sees, and more. Denis Villeneuve doesn't talk down to his audience. He shows you everything and let's you think for yourself.Only one thing had me suspend my disbelief. Jake Gyllenhaal walks excruciatingly slowly throughout the movie. I am aware that it builds more anticipation, but it made me lose focus in every one of those scenes. He also does up his shirt all the way up like an American Liam Gallagher. It's definitely a choice.Having never lived in America, I cant attest to the accuracy of the sets or costumes, but they seem perfectly humdrum and mediocre. I mean this as the biggest compliment, but I would never expect anything interesting to happen in that town or with those people. They are such real people.Overall, this movie is a tough watch. It's extremely graphic at points and psychologically draining. Make sure you're in the right headspace before watching. This movie deserves an 8.5 out of 10, but I'll round it up to 9.

reviews.review_title: too long and nothing happens in most parts
reviews.content: A huge waste of time according to me .With nothing happening most of the time , i couldn't wait to get out of the hall by interval . There were several loopholes in the story . The involvement of the maze or snakes still remains a mystery to me . Couldn't detective Loki(Jake) see Keller's(Hugh Jackman)car parked out of the house in the end . But one has to acknowledge good acting on parts of Hugh and Jake . Nonetheless Mr wolverine cant save a movie without a proper story on the basis of his intensity alone . Plus i have to mention the extreme violence shown in the movie . The torture scenes were a little too much ...

reviews.review_title: All pieces fit deliciously put together
reviews.content: Barry Milland headlines was heart wrenching. After 26 years! I cried for him a lot I actually related to him through one of my loved ones. I am horrified by what he went through and cried about it from the beginning almost.Specially towards the end be aware of several subtle details all of them are revealing and deepens the plot. There is so much to take in. I believe that people who don't appreciate this work enough just missed those little facts that were weaving masterfully until the shocking end, to the last moment when credits start rolling. I am ready to watch the film again it deserves a second watch. Also this movie must be teach in schools and should be revisited by those who work in the Justice Department, from cops to judges.

reviews.review_title: 2 hours too long with an obvious plot
reviews.content: Shocking, slow paced and obvious. I guessed the outcome of every scene and plot twist, the film is far too long and full of endless and pointless scenes. Jakes cop performance was dreadful and considering the plot made him out to be a top detective who'd never left a case unsolved, he didn't connect any evidence and wouldn't have solved anything he hadn't circumstancially stumbled across. His ultimate lack of energy or pace was mind numbing to say the least and with such an incredible cast it was embarrassing that they hardly had anything to do with the story. Jackmans wife was in bed the whole time and the other family were completely overlooked. I could go on and on about this terrible story line that never really made any sense and left 2.5 hours of unanswered questions and pointless plot twists. I couldn't recommend avoiding this film enough!

OK, so this contains spoilers but I will not say a lot.First of all, as someone else on the message boards wrote this movie is just PERFECT if you want to understand whether someone has an understanding of movies or just generally *smart*. The movie contains at least a couple plot holes and a **ton** of stuff just to fill the gaps. I will give some examples. 1-Why did Alex, who didn't even say a word after all that interrogation just randomly spouts that stupid "They didn't cry until I left them". Like what? How dumb is this line. Just think about it, first of all how does he know that he is one of the fathers of the girls. Even if he does know somehow, let's say he saw them from the van, why the hell would you say that to him, and there? Literally anyone could've heard them. There's like 20 people around them, but oh no...2-Going with Alex again, why did he break at the end? Why? This guy literally beat you half to death. Couldn't hit you one more time without killing you, he showered you with boiling water, let you live with your own filth for I don't know how many days. Why the hell in the end would you break *at that perfect time* at the end? So stupid of the writers. 3-How can they not check the ID of someone they take into custody FOR KIDNAPPING OF 2 CHILDREN.!!!! Like what the hell. How dumb is this thing. I called the entire ending the moment they showed the first boy who was kidnapped, and I am sure anyone with a little bit of intelligence did the same. Unless you watched like a couple movies in your life time and you think this movie deserves an 8.1.4-Another thing, why would Keller have his gun in his bag. You tortured someone for 7~ days. Are you afraid to kill the person you are almost *sure* that kidnapped your daughter? Lets say he wanted to hide the gun, why is it not on him? Holly didn't even search him. 5-Oh, oh. I'm adding this after writing everything because it just occurred to me. HOW DUMB is the character Bob Taylor? Maybe I don't understand but please someone tell me. Why would he take the blame for everything? Why would he steal those girls clothes just to make them look like they died? Why would he commit suicide in the first place? Even Holly said she FORGOT about him. Goddamn what the hell.6-I'm sure there is a lot more to say about this *thing* but one last thing. People. Please. Stop. Arguing. Whether. Detective Loki, heard the whistle or not.OF COURSE HE DID, did you watch the ending or did you fall asleep?!He looks around after the 3rd time he hears the whistle, and after the 4th time he literally locks on to a direction! You should be able to deduct that he knows something is up. Just because whoever's genius idea it was to leave it like that, they didn't show him being rescued and put to prison, doesn't mean you shouldn't even pay attention, like god damn.After all this I gotta say, I bashed the movie pretty hard, but it deserved it. Also I should add that after all that stupid bulls*it I still kind of enjoyed the movie. If those dumb plot holes could've been filled with actual writing, this movie would've then deserved an 8.1 or even higher. Maybe not higher. Like I said, EVERYONE saw that ending coming from a mile away.
This movie deserves a 10/10. Absolutely amazing breathtaking performance by huge jackman.

reviews.review_title: This is what happens when you have a simple plot, yet you some reason want to make a nearly 3 hour long movie out of it
reviews.content: I don't mind movies that are giving you little information and the audience have to piece together the story little by little, but this movie is a movie that does not need to be a jigsaw puzzle. The acting is phenomenal, i can't critisize that part, but everything else was tiring, unnecessarily long, like I constantly felt I am wasting my time, because after we hit the 2 hour mark we still don't know anything about the girls or the reason and after the movie ended I still don't know anything. Why did that woman wanted to kill the children again? She talked about some kind of demons, she related this whole thing to religion obviously which I don't mind, and I liked her comparing the parents to demons, but what the hell was this 3 hour long movie? Like one and half hour of this movie was just Keel saying "Just tell me where they are!" so yeah... It could've been way better but it was unnecessarily long and complicated.

reviews.review_title: Great actors wasted on terrible writing
reviews.content: Long, drawn out, jumps around (in a bad way). I mean, let's just talk about how the entire movie shows them in a small, run down town .. that is until Jake Gyllenhaal's cop ( who breaks like every moral code of being the good cop he is that has solved every murder, but hey, he beats a suspect on camera who steals a gun and kills himself...on camera, but we'll ignore that ...) saves the day at the end and all of a sudden is driving through a crowded town. I mean, this was just terrible and did NOT pay off. I kept waiting for the good part ...it never happened! I do not have a clue why it is rated so high....????

I think this is not a movie which can get 8 stars  There is nothing in this movie to get 8 stars. Very average story. The story of this movie is that 2 girls are kidnapped by an old hypocrite lady and after serious labour both girls are saved by a detective.The story of the movie is not like Braveheart, Schindlers list, Gladiator, Avtar, 3 idiots etc but it got 8 stars.

I asked myself this question about the middle of the movie...This introduction is a little harsh, but I can't describe this movie in any other way. It's a roller coaster ride of emotions in which you eventually ask yourself whether the roles of good and evil are really as clear as previously suspected or not.Prisoners has a plot into which everyone could really put himself. In my opinion, this is rarer than some people would think. It's the story of a loving father (Hugh Jackman), whose 6-year-old daughter disappears without a trace.I don't want to reveal too much, but I would like to come back to my introduction, in which I no longer claim to know who is "evil and good" at some point.
I would like to say that you should pay close attention to the character developments of the characters during the course of the film.The cast of the film is spotless and perfect. The two protagonists deliver both very strongly. Hugh Jackman plays phenomenal and Jake Gyllenhaal embodies an equally strong roleMy only criticism would be that the whole thing is moving a little too slow. That's not quite unusual for crime novels, because it stimulates the tension, but in my opinion Prisoners is dragged a little too slowFor a film of this genre, an absolute 9/10
For a film in the world of films, an 8.5/10

Scenes like the one from the begining of this movie seemed long time to be out of cinematografy. You can't admit such "realistic scenes, as part of an artistic act! It is everywhere a tending of being more and more cruel, in arts in general maybe.. Yet you can use fiction and trics of scenery, puppets, etc Otherwise, somewhere you loose arts control.. it is then.. maybe a childrenlike recording at most, perhaps we all Will be lost this way, at the end. We are heading very well toward gladiators and beasts games, toward bullfightings, and other "sports" that make Humankind to be a simple poor animal, the ugliest, instead of being the one that really cares about the others.

It was too long for what it was ! I mean it was a watchable film but left a lot unexplained and wtf was that ending ???!!!! I could go into detail but a few reviews in here have done it fantastically ! I'm more annoyed on how it ended.
Very slow, unnecessarily long, full of loopholes, Jake Gyllenhaal is a disappointment. waste of time, you probably have seen better stories in TV series.
Best movie. And I watch ever the best movie's me to come to you or fbhsjdjshshhsbd.
One of the best thrillers. It contains all the elements that every high-level production should contain. I sincerely recommend.

reviews.review_title: Hugh is the highest tier acting legend
reviews.content: I saw many awesome reviews of this movie but somehow, it never came up up in my watchlist. But when I finally watched it, oh it was one of the smartest decisions of my life. Starting off, Jake Gyllenhaal has always been a class act in virtually all movies he's done. His inspector was super believable and psychologically coherent with the mind of the viewer. Secondly, Hugh Jackman rocked as is his awesome persona in every movie he plays. Oh how can we comprehend the raw aggression shown by a grieving father. The sheer emotions and the dialogues accompanying those emotions were top notch.A must watch drama if you're a fan of 2010s classics.

reviews.review_title: Long ass movie that suddenly stops
reviews.content:
It's long and has no ending. First hour is good then it devolves into the absurd with outlandish plot twists. And then, when you've been ready for the ending for more than 45 min, it jumps to credits...no ending...nothing ..did they run out of film? Money? Were the actors as tired of the story by then as us? Who stops a movie without an ending?Acting was great...and this could have been a great movie...I see now why I just found it 9 years after release....
Not sure who came up with the plot twists but this was like watching a lying 6 year old make up a story that just keeps getting more grandiose.
At moments ascends to the intense level of hair-raising uncomfortableness as Silence of the Lambs.

Hadn't heard anything about this movie, but was very pleasantly surprised. Jackman and Gyallanhal are exceptional and the disturbing topic combined with great movie making, left me thinking about it long after.
It dragged along and felt like it would never end. Definitely was not a fan. The casted characters didn't fit either.

The opening scene had me anxious. I wound up reading the movie's Wikipedia page to find out what happened to the girls. Very interesting and intriguing plot with a few twists. There were a few things that could have been done smarter, but I suppose you're not thinking smart when your adrenaline is running wild due to a missing child.

Was Hugh Jackman wearing a toupee? LOL

Denis Villeneuve and Jake Gyllenhaal return to form with the gut-wrenching, smart detective thriller, Prisoners, which offers emotional twists, complexed characters and a convoluted, yet exceptionally well-polished story. Sir Roger Deakins' beautifully composed shots and lighting, and Jóhann Jóhannsson's exceptional, hair-raising score make the whole movie experience not only suffocatingly great, but also an impeccable visual treat to die for. Both Hugh Jackman and Paul Dano, who are magnificent as always, have delivered extraordinary performances, while Jake Gyllenhaal has given his career-best performance till date.
A classic of a genre, but very quickly it gets tiring.
Way late to the party. Just finished the movie and instantly came here to give it 5 stars

Professionally done but very slow and the characters were laughable enough that one couldn't get lost in the story.  The main family is supposed to be Christian...crosses, music, prayers, prepping (ha!)...  Might the writers have found just one actual Christian to consult?  One would think the faith would have a point but it seems that the only point of it was to make the argument that faith is a load of bunk.  How else could it be that a faithful family suddenly descends into facing adversity with nonstop drug and alcohol abuse and violence?  The minor character of a priest is a blackout drunk who killed a man in his basement.  Of course!  Which leads me to wonder if it was intentional that an apparent bad guy "with the IQ of a 10 year old" is named Alex Jones??  smh...

In Somewhere Pennsylvania, a town with a rampant kidnapping problem, where (for some reason) no one locks their doors or windows, some kids are unforeseeably abducted from their negligent parents.

The protagonist, a belligerent father, continually antagonizes the detective trying to help him while his distraught wife does drugs all day, every day. He then proceeds to abduct, imprison and brutally torture the prime suspect after a lack of evidence renders him incapable of conceiving any other alternatives.

The question of the film centers around the location of the missing children yet, despite his increasingly cruel variations of torture yielding no results over several days, the thought never crosses his mind to ask (or check) if they're at the suspect's home.

Even after a culprit is apprehended, the father continues his exercise in madness until his victim, himself abducted as a child, has to tell him the obvious and directs him to search the first place he should have looked.

Deranged (and drunk), the father goes to the home where his daughter is being held, donning his best handyman disguise. Intent on bungling the rescue of his child, he then places himself in a compromising position, allowing the true villain to (ironically?) imprison him, before the utterly inept authorities arrive to finish what he couldn't.
It definitely keeps you watching but leaves you with some unexplained things…
Long movie, but it keeps you interested and guessing all the way.  Very well written excellent acting.

Tense, bleak, and nasty, this was a film in which I saw much to admire but ultimately found disappointing and even lazy when I saw it on its initial release. Denis Villeneuve went on to Sicario and other excellent films; revisiting this now, I hoped to see what I'd missed the first time, hoping it cohered more than I remembered and that I could be more in line with the prevailing good opinion of the film. 

Much of those things to admire remain, especially Roger Deakins's predictably brilliant cinematography. Shot by a lesser talent, it's probable that the film's atmosphere would be considerably less brooding and uncomfortable. My problem with the central criminal's motivation remains - without descending to spoilers, such situations send at least as many in the opposite direction as they do in the general direction that the villain has gone. 

Hugh Jackman's performance doesn't work (it's far from subtle); Gyllenhaal is better, but his tics seem a little corny. There's little to counteract the problem of Sicario, that the central female character is underwritten; here the wives are adjuncts and those who wait for their men to do what men will do.  None of this makes the film less atmospheric or detracts from the artistry; it's just that for me it's not quite the film it wants to be or that Sicario and his other later films would turn out to be.
Good movie that grabs you by the balls and keeps a firm grip!
This movie is absolutely fantastic. Jake Gyllenhaal made this movie as great as it was

BROOOO THIS MOVIE IS INCREDIBLE!!!!! EVERYTHING ABOUT IT IS SO  GOOD. THE ACTING WAS INCREDIBLE, THE PLOT AND MYSTERY IS SO SMART AND AMAZING, THE CINEMATOGRAPHY IS JUST SO GOOD, THE GORE WAS GREAT, THE ENDING WAS GREAT, THE MUSIC WAS GREAT, I LOVE THIS MOVIE ONE OF MY FAVORITES NOW!!
So we'll done it's very uncomfortable to watch. Acting was fantastic. Jake never disappoints but one of Jackman's best I'd say.
Great movie overall with memorable performances and a story that's both engaging and clever

I would be lying if I said it was my first time watching this film. In honesty, I've only just created a Rotten Tomatoes account and felt obliged to just express, that this is genuinely in my top 3 films of all time. A ridiculously relatable, suspenseful, well put together film, which makes you understand the reason behind certain actions but also the desperation behind it. A fantastic, underrated film that will always be one of my favourites. A masterpiece if you will.

This movie is great. Jakey and Jackman play off each other well and Paul is creepy as hell (as always). If you like slow burns where the anxiety and suspense builds to unbearable heights, this is for you. Comes to a satisfyingly unsatisfying conclusion as well.
Pretty good movie. Slow in beginning but the ending is full of lots of twists.

This film starts well, manages to convincingly work the disappearance of the two children, the problem is later. The main negative point in my opinion is the character of Jake Gyllenhaal, who is the clumsiest detective in Hollywood. He takes time to do everything in the investigation, misses clues, doesn't scan and explore the places properly and gets lost in the search all the time. I liked the way Hugh Jackman gave himself to the role, his performance is good here, but ends up being hampered by a weak script, which throws up several loose ends during 2h30 of the film and takes the one that fits best at the end, throwing it away the others.
Love this movie! I couldn´t take my eyes off of the screen. Great performances by the actors in this suspenseful thriller!

Terrific leads as both JG and HJ are relentless in their performances. The story is a heart-wrenching combination of dread, revenge, and the bizarre. Collectively, it adds up to a fantastic movie, but one that is going to leave you feeling a little gross after watching it. It's an essential thriller.
Inspiring and thought provoking

The whole plot is made according to the standards of detectives: there is a crime, there is a mystery, there are plot twists. The film also says that lynching is bad and will not lead to anything good. Personally, I found this film both interesting and boring. But Jake Gyllenhaal somehow did not hook me, although I like the actor. There are some illogical things in the film, but if not for these illogical things, the ending would be completely different. If we talk about the ending, I did not quite like it, it was strange. I think that this film is suitable for fans of detectives. I advise to watch it

Yet another outstanding film by Denis Villeneuve, "Prisoners" is an intelligently crafted and thought-provoking film whose incredible script and gripping story are only further helped by groundbreaking performances and a director who clearly knows what he's doing.

one of the best movies ever made. In its genre probably the best.
the story and the cinematography is to good. must watch

I took off half a star, because I wanted more closure with the ending, but that's the only flaw I could find. A must see!

Aptly dark cinematography and slow pacing help immerse viewers in this well-crafted abduction thriller which makes the audience fill in pieces of the plot with many key sequences never revealed.  Although some viewers may become confused or frustrated by the lack of conventional story-telling I enjoyed this fresh twist and felt it kept me more engaged throughout and thinking about it the next day. This is to this day, one of the best mystery/thriller films I've ever seen. I loved this movie because it just seems to real. Everything about it was so real and that's where the fear leaped into the audience. The casting was also great as every cast just seemed casual with their role and not a forced look. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal were amazing in their roles but Paul Dano was truly the best in my opinion.

Probably the most generic of Deny's movies I've seen so far, but altogether still an amazingly well-done and satisfying movie.

Like I've watched A LOT of missing person/murder mysteries. Like hundreds. Close to thousands at this point. So the subject matter definitely felt like well-trodden ground and the movie is very in keeping with the tropes of the genre, but the places it took the father character did help to make it unique, as well as the exceptional camerawork and acting.

Although I did feel like I'd seen most of what it had to offer before, that isn't to say it didn't do those story beats well or without finesse, just that after this long it's hard for stories like these to surprise me anymore...

Prisoners is a dark and terrifying look into child abduction and the many varying sides when it occurs. It is shot very well and really captures the bleak atmosphere and has a very good score accompanying it that really draw you into the story. If you can't handle torture and graphic violence then this film will be too much to handle for you and should be avoided. If you can handle the brutality at times, then you will find a lot to like as the film offers mystery, suspense and a thoroughly engaging storyline that sucks you in and doesn't let go until the credits roll. The two and a half hours fly by and has emotional weight by the ton and solid performances from all involved and make for a disturbing but entertaining and emotional film viewing.
This is a must watch that will have you yelling at your tv at the end.
A good crime thriller in the neo-noir tradition. The movie has a somber feel but with a great plot and surprise ending. Great performances by Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman.

This movie is one of those movies that haunts you endlessly after you watch it, and you cant stop thinking about the details like the one guy being the missing child and the ending is like so crazy, It leaves it up to interpretation like did the guy get saved?? because the detective heard the sound but who knows if he saved the guy?!?!?!?! and the torture towards the one guy whos name i cant remember was so sad and Paul Dano played that character so well and even though the character had a happy ending, the story was so tragic. But overall one of my favorite movies ever. WATCH IT

Every time I watch this film the more I enjoy it. Hugh jackman in particular deserved a Oscar nomination for his performance. The film on first viewing has amazing twists and turns, suspense and can be gruelling to watch. Film hides things in plain sight and it works so well. Truly underrated.

Do definitely recommend though

Engrossing from scene one with top notch cinematography and editing, Prisoner finds Denis Vileneuve perfectly crafting a thriller that is tense and emotionally powerful that effortlessly flows with two immaculate perfoemances from Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhall.

While Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners often feels like it is staggering under the weight of its bloated running time and sometimes gets tangled up in the complex web of the plot, it remains an intriguing mystery that keeps the audience guessing until the end.  When two young girls go missing on a rainy Thanksgiving, Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) embarks on an exhausting investigation in an attempt to return the victims to their families.  Aided by strong performances from Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard as the girls' parents, an ominous music score, and some stylish camera work orchestrated by Villeneuve, Prisoners does an excellent job, despite the aforementioned flaws, of establishing an ominous atmosphere and giving some sense of the unimaginable dread that the parents of missing children must experience.
What a masterpiece of a movie, Detective Loki was one of my favorite characters in the movie

This movie was such a thrill. The plot, the unexpected moments, the symbolism, the acting, the drama, and the genuine curiosity that the movie made me feel in response to it makes it one of the best, if not the best of the mystery movies I have ever seen! Some might complain that the movie lasts too long, but at a certain point I seriously could not get enough of it! The ending and what happens to certain characters and why speaks for itself!

I liked the overall vibe and the tension and the actors were very good. However, I felt like the end was a slight anti-climax as we went through this mystery with the mazes, however, this didn't really come back in the end.

That 'Prisoners' is directed by Denis Villeneuve, has cinematography by Roger Deakins and a music score from Johann Johannsson promised a big deal, having seen 'Sicario' and being blown away by its brilliance, especially in these areas. As did having a cast of talented actors such as Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Viola Davis and Melissa Leo.

'Prisoners' almost lives up to the acclaimed hype with most of the film being absolutely exceptional, but doesn't quite make it. Its only major stumbling block is that it spirals out of control towards the end, the tension does slip, there are big lapses in credibility and characters' actions and morality issues become implausible and much less believable. Having been so impressed with the rest of the film, this was a real pity. Maybe it is a little overlong too.

On the other hand, Roger Deakins shows again why he is one of the best contemporary cinematographers in the business with cinematography that's stunning and darkly gritty, also bringing out the visceral horror. The production values in general are impeccably audacious and deeply haunting and the editing is suitably stylish.

Johannsson's music score is suitably ominous and pulse-pulsating, one can actually feel their heart beat with tension and anticipation.

Villeneuve's directing has a beautiful darkness but also a hard edge that is perfect for the story.

While the script is not quite as taut as that for 'Sicario', it does provoke thought and its unsettled nature hits hard. The story is not perfect, but a vast majority of it is nail-biting in tension, frightening in its suspense and very much edge of your seat. It is very violent and is not for the faint hearted because it is so vivid and the turn of events are unpredictable and devastating. It's deliberate in pacing but never dull, despite slacking towards the end.

Characters are interesting, especially Jackman's increasingly unpredictable Keller Dover. You don't condone what he's done and his actions are extreme and one can sort of understand why he resorts to such drastic measures.

Jackman is at his most hard-hitting, a shocking atypical performance that is among his best. Gyllenhaal is firm and understated, Dano is at his most unnerving and at times affecting and Terrence Howard gives one of the best performances he's ever given (showing that with the right material, like here, that he can be good).

Davis and Leo, as to be expected, are outstanding, as is a poignant Maria Bello.

In summary, 'Prisoners' may be long in length yet high in suspense and tension. It had all the makings of an exceptional film, and actually was for most of its running time, but that the ending disappoints as much it does it goes down to being a very good one. 8/10 Bethany Cox
A lengthy but fully enjoyable watch, with a twisting plot that keeps you guessing and on edge till the very end.

Hands down best performance of Hugh Jackmans career. Jake Gylenhaals potrayal of the absolutely determined detective fueled by rage and sorrow was immaculate. Must-see movie for any fan of a quality mystery-drama.
Best movie acting of all time
This is a 2013 movie but its 2022 now. How have I not known about this amazing movie.

This film as some great, multi-layered characters and Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal and the rest of the cast are fantastic in their roles. A tight script, great performances, and eerie cinematography make this movie a great and gripping thriller.

This film is a strong, fierce and engaging crime drama that will capture the attentions of any viewer. From beginning to end the film brilliantly crafts a dramatic mystery that perfectly takes the audience on the emotional journey the characters must endure. The cast was amazing with stellar performances, however it is Hugh Jackman that proves that he is one of the most talented actors in the business, giving a raw and brutal betrayal of a father in desperate search for his lost daughter. Director Denis Villeneuve has an artistic eye for the camera, giving viewers incredible visual storytelling. Although the film may linger a bit too long, each scene justifies their existence in this near perfect film.
Amazing !!!! Great acting and wow what an ending, the whistle. I wish it would have showed what followed but I can only hope he was found
Thought the emotional reactions were done well and had very good unexpected plot twist.

the acting in this movie is amazing don't get me wrong, but the script they were given did the actors wrong. It's almost like this movie was framed as a parent's own desire to bring justice, there was no need for Hugh to be attacking this dude for the majority of this movie, if you really wanted to find your daughter you'd be thinking rationally and trying to actually find them instead of beating this dude senselessly. I got bored and annoyed by the 1-hour mark so if you want to watch something while endlessly scrolling on your phone than this movie is just for you!
maybe this is the best performance of the hugh Jackman, what a pity for that suspect who in the end was just one of the children kidnapped.

A good drama with some great performances. The movie does a great job of keeping you on the edge of your seat to find the truth. I think this movie could have been a little shorter but Gyllenhaal and Jackman's performances are worth the wait.

Wow, where does one even begin? This is easily one of the finest movies I have ever seen, right up there with The Silence of the Lambs and other icons. That the movie was only nominated for its extraordinary cinematography is a slap in the face to the rest of the cast and crew. You know a movie is remarkable and stupendous when it’s very long but you don’t want it to end, when you don’t want to even pause it to use the restroom or get a snack, and you rave about it with your partner for days afterwards and drive co-workers crazy telling them they just HAVE to watch it. The plot is basically about the disappearance of two girls and the investigation that ensues and the relationship between one of the fathers and the lead detective. I’ll just leave it there and not spoil anything for you. This movie is a masterwork of filmmaking. It should be some sort of cinematic crime not to see it in full.
The hints were there, but it is still a huge reveal. Great movie.

Hugh Jackman excels as the anxious father with that typecast aggression echoing from his work as Wolverine. And from this performance flows Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Viola Davis, Melissa Leo, Maria Bello and Terrence Howard who all reach great peaks in a story plot-heavy at times but well worth the watch. One of Denis Villeneuve's best to date as the time ticks and you're on the edge of your seat.
So Fresh: Absolute Must See!
Kept me locked in all the way through. Acting was brilliant and the story gripping.
I really liked this movie!  It kept me thinking and I never predicted the ending, exactly the way I like my suspence thrillers.
Excellent ... little bit long, but , stay with it ..some great acting , great script. I never guessed the ending ..
Prisoners succeeds in dark and emotional, but maybe not for all the right reasons - it drags on for more than it needs to

Some scenes felt quiet and tough to hear people speaking, and because of that the movie felt slow at certain points.
That being said, the simple plot kept giving and giving through each section of the movie.
One of my favourites ever!
Good movie but wayyyyy to slow
Went in blind not expecting too much but holy was I positively surprised. Great one!

It was a good movie but too slow
everyone was intruding everywhere:))))))))
Great acting and movie, but bad ending
So good and disturbing. A film with many complexities and layers. I still hate Melissa Leo's character, after all these years :)
Amazing in it's depth, honesty and complexity. An enlightening story about the self-replicating capabilities of pain, hate and violence to those who wanna see.
Perfect thriller in every way

"Prisoners" directed by Denis Villeneuve.

"A man who's lost everything is capable of anything"

Prisoners is one of the best, if not the best, crime thriller of the century. An incredibly well executed movie that ties you almost instantly to your chair.

Denis Villeneuve is hands down one of the best directors of this generation and his work in Prisoners is fantastic, you can really see how passionate he is about his job. Everything, and I really mean everything is well tought and well put together. Roger Deakins again nails with the cinematography. There is literally not a single frame i would change.

The acting is from another world. Hugh Jackman is top notch, the range of this man in this movie is incredible and comes to show how talented he really is. I feel like I have nothing to say about Gyllenhaal because he is fucking incredible in every movie he does, but he was specially good in here. Viola Davis and Maria Bello were great and portrayed the role of desperate and hopeless mothers so well. The biggest surprise in this movie was Paul Dano. The man can act!

Prisoners is a fascinating crime story. It has a lot a foreshadowing and deep symbolism. Every line and every shot are important to the story and that's what makes this film so great. It's very unpredictable, which is perfect in a crime/thriller movie. It is a masterpiece and it's Villeneuve's work at his finest. One of the best movies of the 10s and my second favorite from Denis, only after Blade Runner 2049.

Hugh Jackman at his best and and equally powerful performance by Jake Gyllenhaal.
The story keeps you on the edge of your seat and the ending is deserved of the brilliant writing acting and directing.
A must watch!

[⭐️94%]

When you have a suspenseful and dark story, beautiful cinematography and top actors, all helmed by a great director, you get a fantastic film.

People may question beforehand why the film must be 150 minutes long, and after watching you will know why. The plot itself doesn't fill up that entire runtime, however the way it is told does. On many occasions the camera lingers in certain scenes to either build tension or allow the viewer to take in what is on show. 

As mentioned, Prisoners (2013) is both a beautiful and horrible movie in the sense at how well it is shot and uses the dialogue efficiently, whilst also displaying how far a father would go to protect his daughter. Hugh Jackman's rage shines through making him terrifying to watch, instantly grabbing your attention.

Prisoners (2013) is a tense film from start to finish thanks to Denis Villeneuve's directorial style of showing and telling the story, not to mention fierce performances from all actors and actresses involved. Each rewatch benefits your experience as you notice and understand more details more and when exactly they come into play.
One things that I have always really liked about this movie is it always keeps you guessing. This film is so well done and the acting performances are amazing.

One of my favorite movies of all time, if not, my #1 favorite. Where to begin… The casting is perfect and the acting throughout is amazing and realistic. The score is chilling, haunting, but also beautiful at the same time, it enhances a scene for the better, making it suspenseful, sad, or scary. The cinematography is amazing, the shots in this movie can make you feel the entire scene and absorb everything you are seeing without any cuts ruining it, and it can also make you feel claustrophobic at times. Some scenes in this movie had me on the edge of my seat and my heart pounding because of how gripping a certain scene was, and I only watched this movie on my small iPhone 7 screen. This isn't a horror movie, but sometimes I would squint or get scared because a scene would be that heavy. This movie is a mystery, and is not predictable at all, it deals with family and trauma, and explores how far a man would go to save a  family member. This movie also has tons of symbolism, whether it's purposeful or not. And the ending… oh my god the ending… It's hard to describe in words what emotions you go through in the ending, but at the same time I don't want to spoil it, so I'll just say that the ending was cool. But this is probably the best directed movie ever, thanks to Denis Villeneuve, one of the my favorite directors of all time, after watching this movie. This is my favorite movie of all time.
Sometimes harrowing but excellent.
Every Denis Villenueve movie is either a masterpiece or almost a masterpiece. This film is one of his masterpieces, though not as good as Sicario and subjectively Blade Runner 2049.
A competently made and acted film but it was overlong and laboured. Not a thriller I'll remember and strangely didn't feel particularly absorbing.

October—Villeneuve—#2

I thought they were in the tree...

"Making children disappear is the war we wage with God. Makes people lose their faith, turns them into demons like you."

The journey leading up to Dune continues with Denis Villeneuve's 5th featured length movie. His first three, August 32nd on Earth, Maelström, and Polytechnique, weren't very good for me, and only until his 4th, Incendies, which I pretty recently watched, did Villeneuve got the right budget to make great movies. 

I watched Prisoners a while ago, and I remembered not really digging it. However, after this rewatch, I totally loved this movie. First of all, Hugh Jackman's intense performance outshined everyone else. The way his character lost his humanity while trying to find the answer was both heartbreaking and terrifying. Jake Gyllenhaal was also great with his change in demeanor as a cop. The way he smiled at first and then turned violent got on my nerve a little bit. 

The story itself was intense, slow, yet intriguing. For 2 hours and 30 minutes, I did not feel bored, and only got more gripped into the story as the movie progressed. It did not feel long. The plot was a harsh look at the way people lost their faith or tried to cling to their faith without losing themselves to hatred. 

Probably the best aspect that elevated the mystery was the maze symbol that became more apparent toward the end. Not only was it integral to the plot, but the mazes without a way out also served as prisons that the characters got stuck in. Some got imprisoned in captivity, childhood trauma, revenge, finding answers, and hatred of God.

Overall, an amazing and gripping thriller that I wanted more of. 9/10

Prisoners (A+)
One of the most captivating thrillers. A lot of it was hard to watch and I would not recommend to those who don't like brutal movies as there is a lot of uneasy scenes. If you are someone who likes mysteries and well thought out plots then this is definitely a must watch. The casting was amazing and honestly the twists were shocking. Heart was racing in the latter end of the movies. It all starts slow but ends in glorious fashion where pieces of info shown earlier actually play into the final product. I hope other thrillers look at this movie as inspiration for what they should make their movies to be. Lots of thrillers are predictable and don't have this amount of thought put into the storyline.
Wow! Hugh Jackman's performance is one of the best I've ever seen, and I absolutely love the way that small details are critical to the story, which ties it neatly in a bow! Incredible!

With a complex story filled with lots of emotional moments that make you question, who is actually the bad guy? Jake and Hugh star in this mystery thriller about a young girls kidnapping and exactly how far a father will go to get her back. With a twist to end the film, it leaves something to be desired but at the same time, feels full.
Wow, what a thrilling ride! Despite some red herrings and plot contrivances, it packs an emotional wallop. Villeneuve knows how to tell a story. Gripping from start to finish.

Prisoners is a wildly gripping thriller that mostly earns its bloated runtime through great acting from Jackman and Gyllenhaal, a resonating story, and a twisting plotline. While its revelations from its conclusion leave a bit to be desired, the journey there is downright harrowing. Prisoners is an easy recommend to just about anyone with 2 and half hours of time on their hands.
An excellent illustration of that situation when you get obsessed on blaming someone of something he or she isn't to blame. Sad story, and not a happy ending at all, but very good plot.

I thought it was WAY too long, way too unrealistic and ultimately a huge let down that made the entire movie seem like a waste of time. Even after the 2hr 33min running time the movie leaves so many loose ends and unexplained points that I felt cheated.
Absolutely fabulous! Didnt see the time go by! Immediately gripping! A lot of depth! Addictive! Never saw the ending coming! Just wish it carried on for a couple of more minutes at the end

Really enjoyed Prisoners.  The acting was stellar throughout, from every cast member, but Hugh Jackman was the absolute standout for me.  Probably my favorite performance of his to date.  I still don't know if I loved Gyllenhaal's performance, but overall, he fit the bill.  This had a real feeling of genuine crime thriller for me and was brilliantly directed.  The payoff was worth the wait and the final act's twist was unexpected.  I would've likely given this 4.5/5 stars if it wasn't so long.  I felt they could've shorted to 90-100 minutes though.  With it being over two hours, it resulted in some needless dialogue at times.  That said, highly recommend watching/never letting your kids leave your house again!
Great performance by Jackman. It has Amazing cinematography work

Strong performances set the tone here. Now, if you are the parent of small children, the grandparent of small children, anything like that, you might want to skip this one. This one could rattle you, especially when the reveal happens. Yowza. It is longer than the normal flick, but the time moves quickly due to the gripping story telling. Nightmare inducing stuff.
Amazing piece of filmmaking and powerful acting performances. The story was gripping from start to finish. A+ movie.
Dark movie, it's always showing on TV so I think I've seen it multiple times. Very dramatic, as Hugh Jackman usually is, but just another father looking for his kids movie.

As a parent, Prisoners is a hard movie to watch. The acting is superb, but the story just wrings your heart and makes you feel angry and helpless. Denis Villeneuve does an admirable job of creating a sense of dread without completely diminishing hope. This is a very compelling drama, however it's not a viewing experience I'd like to repeat anytime soon.

Having watched Prisoners countless amounts of times, it is a film that gets you on the edge of your seat every time you watch it. The acting on display is incredibly strong, particularly the performance of Hugh Jackman. Jackman manages to encapture the true sadness, anger, desperation, and determination of a Father who is at risk of losing his daughter. This is definitely Hugh's best performance. His acting is complimented greatly by Jake Gyllenhaal, whose performance as Detective Loki is impeccable. The mannerisms of Detective Loki (which Jake Gyllenhaal thought of himself) bring so much characterization to the role. However, as amazing as the performances are, this does not outshine the equally impressive directing, screenplay and cinematography. A classic. 10/10.

Prisoners - 10/10. Denis Villeneuve debuted into Hollywood with this terrifically intense crime drama. Shot incredibly by the legend Roger Deakins and with superb performances from Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Terrence Howard, and Melissa Leo, Prisoners is an excellent thriller which follows both the victim's and police's storylines. Its quite an intense and raw film, and really plays up the tension and intensity of the story. Its an incredible film, which helped launch the career of Villeneuve and catapult him to the upper echelons of directing talent. Whats great about Prisoners is that it doesn't shy away from the hardships that a kidnapped child's parents' would go through. Jackman plays the role of a distraught father on a mission to find his child extremely well. This is by far his best performance of his career. His rage is real and you can feel he put a lot of energy into this character. Gyllenhaal as the cop gives a really underrated performance in this film, and Leo gives a really good and creepy performance. But by far the best aspect of this film is Deakins's cinematography. How he captures the cold and dark nature of the story really shows the legend's mindset in terms of filming sequences. This film is probably my fave Villeneuve film, and one that deserves more attention than his other work in my opinion.
Just yes! Go watch. Just do it!
Predictable storyline and ending
Overly dramatic and rather predictable, even worse than that, very slow much of the time.  You could lose half an hour of film and still know more than you need.  Big names for such a meh movie.
From the best movies I have ever seen in my life but what the heck happened to Keller dover
91%. Close to a 5 star. Great suspense story. Hugh Jackmans character is super intense and an intriguing character. Definitely worth the rewatch

Intens and well made abduction drama thriller with a changing plot, psychologically challenging even just to watch. Some of the best actors working hard under a steady and demanding direction, but occasionally the characters get either overexaggerated or are used too obviously intentional rather than deliberately confusing. It's dark, cold, rainy, cluastrophobic and feels basically real, but good stories are difficult to end and sadly there are also some logical flaws that spoil the total from being absolutely top notch.

Prisoners is one of these films that will make you spend 2 hours and then surprise you in the last 30 minutes. A great film that has great acting performances, cinematography, directing, screenplay, and everything. 

Prisoners really surprised me with everything. Didn't expect the film to go to where it's going. Its story is so great and I believe that's thanks to the build-up that took 2 hours. Although it's a long time. But, in the end, it will all make sense and the pieces are all put together perfectly. Every film is famous for a specific scene but it's hard to find one in this film because there are so many so it's hard to pick. I'll be honest, at the first, I didn't like that the film was taking too much time to tell the story and it was giving us one piece after the other but at the end, we were able to put all of them together and it gave us a masterpiece.

I believe that this is Jake Gyllenhaal's second-best performance (Nightcrawler being the first). He was able to present Detective Loki in such a unique way that only Jake himself is able to play. For those who don't know, Detective Loki's tattoos, rings, and rapid blinking were all Jake Gyllenhaal's ideas. I believe that the rings and the tattoos have meanings behind them which makes Detective Loki an interesting character that we all want to know more about. Now for Hughe Jackman,  I believe that this is his best performance even better than Wolverine. In many scenes, you could feel his pain as a father who lost his daughter especially in those scenes where he was screaming and yelling at the top of his lungs. You can feel the pain in his voice. Overall, the acting in this film is ON POINT.

Denis Villeneuve's way of directing this film is very unique. He was able to give us drama, Thriller, Crime, and many more using his directing and the little small details that you might think don't matter but they all will at the end. Roger Deakins with his great cinematography/camera movements were beautiful, the film really has many shots that are beautiful. Also, the colors and the editing really helped to give the audience that thriller/crime vibe. 

Overall, this film has everything. Acting, cinematography, editing, directing, and even the music/soundtrack may be the most part that many didn't notice. But, in some scenes, you could hear the beautiful soundtrack of Jóhann Jóhannsson playing in the background and giving you that suspense/thriller feel. Great film that the more you get deep into it and notice the little details, the more you like it. 

My rating is 9/10

Certainly watchable, with intriguing characters and Villeneuve's trademark flair that we also see in Enemy and Blade Runner 2049. Gyllenhaal is reliably superb, while Jackman does his best despite delivering what some might see as an overly shouty, belligerent performance and scattershot lines making it difficult for the audience to sympathize with him. Viola Davis offers up a surprisingly complex supporting role. Paul Dano also steals the show in the few scenes that he has. The final payoff didn't quite warrant the two-ish hours before it of slow, painful buildup.

The ambition of the film makes it worth the watch, which perhaps isn't the greatest argument. The themes of internal and external prisons, along with religion are intriguing enough to allow for thoughtful reflection despite dissatisfaction with a few plot points. The priest was an example of missed potential, while the main red herring of the mystery convoluted the plot and seemed an artificial implant rather than a worthwhile diversion. 

I simply enjoy that Prisoners builds multiple characters well in order to explore the implications and effects of a kidnapping upon those close to the victims. The effort is not perfect or unblemished, but this indirectly adds to the humanity surrounding the film. The visual style and good suspense also bump this one up to a positive rating.

The whole movie builds on coincidences and stupidity of the characters.

Spoiler:

First of all. Why has the detective no partner? A Partner would like... make total sense. Okay. Ill start right after the police got the kid but he isnt answering to anybody. Except to the father when he got released. Because...? yup, theres no excuse at all in the end. It doesnt make sense. He told him that something that makes him the prime suspect in the case. Spoiler: No one cared about him. Literally. The police not believing anything is only the cherry on the cake. Okay. Noted. Its even noted that the police is looking everywhere. Except in the house of the kidnapper. Ok. Given, theres no trace at all - even with dogs - that the children were ever in this house. MAYBE the tracks of the abandoned car only moving 3 meters would make anyone with half a brain thinking "why would anyone move this car recently? maybe Ill look under it.". Nope. No one will notice these tracks. Not even with a full team in the end thats currently digging the whole garden to find dinosaurs. They cant find anything. Ok. No Tracks. Noted.

Theres a new suspect, he flew from the police after he touched a teddy. Now theres only one suspect. No one cares about the first suspect, they don't even watching him. Because...? yeah. He wasnt  it, because he didnt admit it. Check. Via pure luck a witness saw the new suspect and could give the police the tag of his car. 

They find him at home. Better call the detective and drive away as far as we can.

The detective arrived at the house of the suspect. Everyone currently thinks: This is it. There are the kids. SWAT should arrive soon but instead:

NOT EVEN ONE POLICE CAR WAS AT THIS HOUSE. The detective entered ALONE the house of the suspect. A Partner would come in handy, but that would make the movie less suspensful. Ok. Given.

Meanwhile the first kidnapper got kidnapped by the father. Somehow the kidnapper  manages to withstand 24/7 tortue and breaks only after 7 Days and tells him they were in the maze. How would this kid doesnt tell anything in the first couple of days? Besides the cheap movie trick "better let the kid misstreat an animal before he got kidnapped, so the viewer agrees with this whole torture thing." 

Ok. Even given that. The detective now follows the father, because maybe he has anything to do with the kidnappers missing.  Where would you hide if you followed someone in a car. The best place would be.... in the middle of a crossing in traffic. Smartest thing to do: Just wait. After a while a truck arrives and honks loudly. The father noticed him (no shit) and didnt lead him into his secret house. 
 
Somehow now the detective thinks: The only way to find his hideout is reading the newspaper of the last years that contained the name of the father. Obviously he finds the adress and drives to this house. Again: Alone. 
So he breaks into the hideout. Knocking? Why? This doesnt make any sense. He only knocks on houses when hes locking for a suspect involved kidnapping children. This is something serious: A random person may or may not have been kidnapped. 

So hes in the house and finds the father sleeping on the ground. he wakes him up and aks what up. "yeah, im sleeping way better in this creepy house on a cold floor than at home". Detective "yeah, cool, can you show me around?". Father. "well, of course, I have only kidnapped and tortured someone upstairs. I could of course ask for a search permit or why you are even in my house - but the better thing to do is showing you everything"

Yadayada - The cop is just one room away from the kidnapper. His phone rings and: 

One children could escape after 7 days. How? Uhm. She ran away.

Good, we should stop looking at this house and drive fast with separate cars to the hospital. Its a good thing that I have a police car with blue light and you got a car. 

Probably the reason because the father arrived way earlier than the detective. 
 So, father in the room and asks the child anything about clues etc. 
The kid now tells the father that she have seen him. Perfect clue. The father clicks and thinks:"well, I was at the mothers house - OF COURSE". So he rushes to the exit. Police is suspicious, "block the exits!" "lock the hospital down, all units check every exit!"

So the father escapes without a scene and drives to the house of the lady. yeah, no one is following him, he escaped the hospital so we cant follow him. 

Father arrives at the house and asks the nice lady if he can come in to fix anything in the house. The lady naturally agrees, this wouldnt be weird at all. 
The father proceeds to put all his tools on the kitchen counter and doesnt watch the lady at all. Why would he? So he said "I dont want to hit you" and turns around at looks into the smallest .22 caliber gun in the universe. Picture this: He stands 2 meters to the lady. Hugh fucking Jackman build like a bear against a small women with a very tiny revolver. He could easily move or try something - because lets be real: This thing wont stop him.  But Nope. He does everything what she demands, even including drinking a knockout cocktail. So they go outside, the lady now directly behind him pointing the gun to.. something, not the father thou. So naturally he doesnt do anything (the same guy that tortured someone else with pure violence for 7 days straight) and does again everything she says. Only after he 
 looks into a black hole said "you have to shoot me if you want me to jump in there". Well. This was maybe a better idea before she was standing 5 meters apart from you and just shot him in the leg. (neighbors dont care/exist).

So he jumps into the hole. 
Meanwhile the best detective on this planet, after they have found the kidnapped kidnapper, had the job to tell the nice lady that his child was found. Nope, not via phone. He has to come in person. He knocks, no one answers - the lady currently kills the child. So what does a good detective when he should bring a good answer and no one is answering the door. Yes, obviously he opens the door and searches for the lady - in the end he shot her and she shot him in the head. Yeah, of course "tis but a scratch" and he can bring the child safely to the hospital.

So. The Children are safe. Not because the father. Not because the great detective work. It was just random. The first child could escape via luck and the second child survived because the detective knocked on this evening on the door, which was just a stupid coincidence. 

The story of the second suspect isnt really tellworthy, because this was the laziest red hering I have ever seen. He got arrested and catches the gun of the great detective in the interrogance room. Naturally the detective and the police all have their weapons still and are looking baffled that he kills himself in slowmo. Nope, they dont try to stop him.

So. This is one of the best movies out there and im here and wondering: WHY IS NO ONE NOTICING ANY OF THIS?

Enjoy the movie.
This movie is under appreciated, under-awarded, and underrated. (As seen on this site). Prisoners is a perfect thriller.

_Prisoners_ is a "complete" movie in the sense that no detail is forgotten, and everything comes together like the pieces of a jigsaw puzzle. The final piece, in the very last scene, is perfect.
Yes, it's overwrought and melodramatic. Hugh Jackman just devours the scenery as the father of a missing little girl. He overdoes it, but perhaps that's what filmmaker Denis Villeneuve wanted....? There are also some illogical bits. And the villain, whom we finally discover in the final 30 minutes (after a few red herrings), is pretty ridiculous. But those flaws are offset by Jake Gyllenhaal's terse, understated performance as the cop on the case. This may be the best role I've ever seen him in.
Roger Deakins' cinematography is magnificent, especially in the "race to the hospital" scene.
This is one of those films in which, after viewing, you go "Whew." It puts you through the wringer. And----no spoilers, but after the 2 1/2 hours of hell we go through with the characters, it has a gratifyingly happy ending.
It's okay. The story is kinda of interesting. But it's way too long and pretty forgettable.

Prisoners' mystery story feels fresh, if not overly intense. Its pacing slow-cooks the tension to point that the viewer may forget to breath, which can be a good thing. Its subtle trail of breadcrumbs holds viewer interest without letting go. Its third act has weight, but without levity its dark tone can feel overplayed. Hugh Jackman is in typical A-lister form, and so is supporting actor Jake Gyllenhaal. The film's dark tone can be a bit much for some viewers who don't prefer to be left in that dark place. A dose of levity may be called for, despite the severity of the circumstance.

My word what a film, a beautiful, sad and revengeful movie. Makes you think what would you have done if you were the father. The performances of the actors were so brilliant that I actually felt they pain. Hugh Jackman how he didn't even receive a Oscar nom or even the fucking Oscar itself is man blowing. The story alone was brilliant every piece and character was 10/10 and there isn't a lot of them out there from the dead victim in the priests house to the sick man with the mazes my word it was breathe taking.  This film is a must see and is fucking brilliant

Prisoners is a well-acted, suspenseful, gritty crime drama thriller.

The film mainly focus on the choices taken and the consequences faced by the characters when worst things happen to them.

It asks the question: how far are you willing to do to protect your family? It explores human behaviour when such crime are happening to us, blurring the lines between good and bad people.

The story does unfolds at a slow pace, but the dramatic scenes performed by the cast will keep you engaged. Hugh Jackman and Jack Gyllenhaal both giving Oscar-worthy performances here, defining and developing their characters with various layers of emotions.

The film's atmosphere, heavy rains, stormy days and icy cold winter managed to create a dark, dreadful environment to make up the dreary and haunting mood in the film. Every violent action taken by the characters are acts of desperation given that they are running out of time.

The Cinematography is just gorgeous, the score is hauntingly beautifully, absolutely would recommend.

The only reason this Masterpiece doesn't rate higher on here is that critics always mark down crime drama. And to be perfectly honest, so do I. This is an exception though, it's intelligent and morally complex, incredibly well acted by a very well chosen cast. The cinematography and editing is unusually good for a film in this genre too.

It actually reminds me a lot of one of Christopher Nolan's early films called Insomnia... Another criminally underated film in the Nolan catalog.

It's not exactly an upper of a vibe but it's well worth your time.

Prisoners is an intricate and utterly jarring drama/thriller exploring themes of family and obsession. It's a maze that draws out our most basics feelings of uncertainty and fear and leaves the viewer in thought of its many implications.

Even through the slow burning narrative, 'prisoners' is so richly gripping and compelling, with a superb achievement through Denis Villeneuve's darkly themed and strong directing, as well as the amazing acting from Hugh and Jake through their hugely convincing roles.

A riveting and complex police procedural that even develops into a character study.

Prisoners is about two families, the Dovers and Birch's, of which their two 6 year old girls were abducted and the only suspicious person was played by Paul Dano, whose RV was parked not too far from the neighborhood they live in. The Dovers were played by Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello and the Birch's were Viola Davis and Terrence Howard. Detective Loki was assigned to their find the children and the culprits behind the abduction. I believe the strongest performance came from Loki who was played by Jake Gyllenhaal. He should have been nominated for his role who has always been able to solve all his cases. When the police couldn't do anything about it and running out of options Hugh takes action into his own hands and takes Paul Dano as a prisoner. Denis Villeneuve directed a great cast with a great script but it was well worth it.

Prisoners is a raw and dark movie. I generally like this kind of movies, but this one particularly seemed perfect. I think that the performances by Paul Dano, Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal are awesome, and it sends the message that a parent could do anything for their children. Prisoners Pros: Fantastic Acting Amazing Directing Terrific Screenplay Stunning Cinematography Magnificent Editing Brilliant Pacing Intriguing Storyline Strong Musical Score and Sound Design Filled with a great emotional depth Encompasses gripping suspense Cons: Hugh Jackman’s performance can feel a bit repetitive at times Overall Grade: A (9.5/10)

Prisoners, Villeneuve's first English-language film, owned me its 154-minute run time and had me hooked from the opening Lord's Prayer. I can't believe it (1) isn't more popular and (2) that it only has an (80) RT critics' score. Gyllenhaal as the live-and-die-by-his-job detective — he literally doesn't have an interaction that doesn't have to do with the case — is tortured from falling short lead after lead. We are told that Detective Loki has never let a case go cold. What is cold, however, is the ice-water in his veins, as he didn't even flinch finding a moldering body in a priest's dank basement/secret compartment. I've always said that Joaquin Phoenix is the most underrated actor in Hollywood (a statement I'll need to amend now that he's won an Oscar for Best Actor), but in terms of thrillers, Gyllenhaal is right up there with performances in Zodiac (a film I love but have not watched since starting this blog), and Nightcrawler, where I know he gives a fantastic performance and is on my list. Gyllenhaal's counterpart is Hugh Jackman as Keller Dover, the grieving father of his missing child. While Jackman's accent might slip here and there, his character teeters from sympathetic to terrifying from one scene to the next. I must say, his wood shower torture device was showcased both his will to find his daughter and his craftsmanship as a carpenter. The misdirections are effective at keeping the viewer engaged and, of course, there is a plausible twist that was satisfying. I was afraid maybe the ending was going to ruin the movie, but really loved how they brought a prop from the beginning full-circle.

Prisoners is an enthralling slow burner that pairs impeccable acting with vivid storytelling. In this brooding thriller, Denis Villeneuve explores the ways in which individuals react and respond to trauma. The story revolves around two contrasting individuals and their separate attempts to locate two missing girls. Detective Loki, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, is stoic and enigmatic. His composure is calm and his demeanor is reticent. Keller Dover, played by Hugh Jackman, is a devout and caring father, whose faith is challenged as he battles with decadence to locate the missing girls, one of which is his own. The small details in this film bring it to masterpiece status. The cinematography by Roger Deakins is crisp and bleak. The score by the late JÃ³hann JÃ³hannsson is eerie and haunting. Dense symbolism and motifs are weaved through the film, as Villeneuve reflects on morality, faith, and persistence in the trial of tragedy.

Available on PL Netflix now, I encourage y'all to watch because it has an amazing ending, not everything goes smoothly and fine, just as IRL. Plus, Jake is amazing and I fully appreciate his character's creation.

Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners (2013) is a shocking depiction of disturbing criminal patterns and creepy adults. Villeneuve uses clever visual clues and stunning cinematography from Roger Deakins to key in the audience to hidden meanings and revealing moments in this crime mystery.

The detective narrative captured by Jake Gyllenhaal's brilliant understated role is impressive unto itself. Villeneuve imagines an investigation from start to finish with realistic developments and decision making process. In the process, Villeneuve and writer Aaron Guzikowski demonstrate how the police construct a character study of a perpetrator and find missing children. Prisoners shows detectives at their hardest working and the mental toll they undergo to save lives. Prisoners simultaneously reveals flaws in the process of capturing suspects and searching for evidence.

Similarly, Prisoners debates the moral necessity for torture and the ethics of interrogation with Hugh Jackman's character. As much as Prisoners sympathizes with the victims of kidnapping in the children themselves as well as the parents and siblings in a larger community. Prisoners also strives to prove the value of trusting police work instead of going rogue and conducting private torture and imprisonment. You could argue that Jackman's character's efforts lead to nothing but trouble and only hinder the detective's investigation. Jackman does uncover several key clues, but in the end, he only endangers himself regardless of finding the killer. It's a tough visual to appreciate as Prisoners asks the audience what is right, despite what we would like to think that we would do if put in the same situation.

All in all, Prisoner's is a masterful thriller that is so suspenseful in the capable hands of director Denis Villeneuve. The two leading actors, Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal, keep you engaged with each scene leading to more suspense.

The supporting roles from the unsettling Paul Dano, the frightening Melissa Leo, the tragically hurt Maria Bello and Viola Davis, and the upset and uncertain Terrence Howard are all fantastic. Their respective roles all culminate in a moving cast of impressive performances. They each build up the tragedy of Prisoner's dark narrative. 

While Prisoners can be imposing by its bleak nature, I think it is a captivating film in its own right. Perhaps director Denis Villeneuve's best film even. Prisoners is a stomach churning meld of The Lovely Bones, The Boston Strangler, and Zodiac. Part police procedural, part sociopath character study, part victim viewpoint, and all entertaining, if upsetting. Through all the pain, each person is left a prisoner of their own situation.

We are all prisoners of something.

The really amazing thing about this film is that it shows that all of the characters are prisoners without telling you. Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) is a prisoner of his past. Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is a prisoner of his need to protect his family at all costs. And so on, and so forth.

The performances in this movie are absolutely outstanding. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal are the obvious ones, but I thought that Paul Dano and David Dastmalchian did excellent jobs portraying creepy, disturbing characters.

I really liked the cinematography. It's beautiful and dark and claustrophobic. The musical score is also orchestrated incredibly well, with tense atmospheric tracks to amplify the stress when needed.

The plot of Prisoners is intricate, but not overwrought or convoluted. It's easy enough to follow if you're paying attention, and allows the viewer to make connections on their own. It's fascinating and stressful to watch the characters discover the pieces and fit them together. Everything is important.

Most importantly, this film asks very difficult questions. If you were in the shoes of Keller Dover or Franklin Birch (Terrence Howard), what would you do? Would you follow the path of Keller, or the path of Franklin? Would either choice be right or wrong? Would it destroy your faith, the way that the perpetrator intended?

Overall, Prisoners is a fantastic morally grey movie that forces the viewer to think about what they're being shown.

This is a good movie in my opinion.  It has it's flaws and is pretty long at 2.5 hours.  Good performances by Jake and Hugh.  It does answer almost all of the questions you have and goes into the history of how this all happened.  I'm happy that I watched it.

Strengths: Denis Villeneuve is 4 for 4 in terms of directing great films. This was another as he nailed everything this movie needed. The tense moments, the emotional beats, and getting the most out of his actors. Hugh Jackman (Keller Dover) gives one of his more underrated performances ever. We know him as Wolverine, but here, he played the part of a desperate man at the end of his line so well. It shouldn't be overlooked. Jake Gyllenhaal (Detective Loki) was also great, as was Viola Davis (Nancy Birch). She didn't get a lot of screen time, but she made the most of it. Her plea to Paul Dano's (Alex Jones) character is one of the best scenes. Dano is great, as is the short run by Melissa Leo (Holly Jones), who is nearly unrecognizable. Again, it comes back to Villeneuve. He sets the perfect dark tone and the mood of the film is perfect. It takes you on a psychological whirlwind as the mystery unfolds and it's quite the journey.

Weaknesses: There aren't many. As usual, I couldn't really get into Terrence Howard's (Franklin Birch) performance. Something about him in a lot of movies leaves something to be desired and I felt the same way here. The twist involving Leo's character isn't that hard to predict, taking ab it away from the moment itself. Also, the movie is very long and probably could use some trimming of the fat. Cut down to two hours, it would have probably flowed better.

Overall: A gritty mystery film that is masterfully handled. Led by a great director and stunning performances from its leads, especially Jackman and Gyllenhaal, it ranks among the best films of the past five years.
one of my all time favorite movies a great thriller, you feel it's at the peak all the way through!

An exceptional film. It's dark and tense, and gives you a sense of dread, and maybe even disgust, du to the fact that those things could really happen. The story is interesting and well paced, even for a 2h30 long film. But what really takes the show is the duo of actors, Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal both deserve an Academy award, it's some of the best and most convincing acting I've ever seen. Overall, it's a grim film, not for everyone's taste, but it's still a great piece of cinema. Recommended !!
