Amazing movie with a great ending.

Denis Villeneuve didn't debut with Prisoners, but it was this movie that put him on the map as one of the most exciting new talents to come around in sometime. Prisoners is about a pair of girls who are abducted which leads to an investigation and search effort by the father of one girl played superbly by Hugh Jackman. This is a tough but rewarding film to sit through and the pacing is good- you will be transfixed throughout. The acting is superb and everyone from Terence Howard and Jake Gyllenhaal to Paul Dano and Melissa Holly shine, but the star act is Jackman who should have received more accolades for his turn as the distraught father in this movie. Cinematography is stunning as is the direction.
a bloated movie thats typical of the junk today. just watch the first 20 minutes and youll see what i mean. bland and boring, with the promise of some torture going on later on.

Denis Villeneuve's psychological mystery film about two children who are kidnapped and a father who goes on a vigilante hunt for justice, paralleled by a police detective trying to solve the case through legal means. It's a very, very well directed film that's extremely taut and one of the most tense film experiences I've ever sat through. The story doesn't give you everything, instead forcing the viewer to connect the dots rather than treat us like idiots. It's an exceptional piece of crime film and another definite suggestion from me.

A film teeming with symbolism and emotion, Prisoners is another example of the brilliance of director Villeneuve. Once again, the dark, mysterious, ugly parts of humanity that are revealed when we're backed into corners are highlighted with an almost grotesque fascination. Gyllenhaal and Jackman are stellar, driving the story with impassioned, heart-wrenching performances. Despite what I felt was quite a contrived ending, this is a solid suspense with a gripping plot.

Prisoners is a tough, long watch. But it’s so well-made and brutal that it makes you its prisoner, in a good way. This film has an impeccable script with a Jackman and Gyllenhaal on their A-games. It’s one of the darkest movies I’ve ever seen, rivaling Se7en for the amounts of rain and darkness without ever seeing the sun. This really does add to the movie though. It’s not something you notice while watching, but something that enhances your dread. It jumps from suspect to suspect quickly but without discrediting or having you forget about the last. It’s a movie you won’t want to watch all of the time, but with such a script and acting along with the atmosphere, you should make sure you watch it at least once. In fact, the script is so good that you almost forget how terribly long the runtime is. 9/10

Prisoners is one of my favorite movies of all time. The directing, acting  (Jackman and Gylenhaal gave two of the best performances I've seen in a long time) and the cinematography and soundtrack are haunting! I've seen this three times now and I can't remember the last time I was so invested in a movie. This is nothing short of a masterpiece.

A movie that will shock many. A thrilling leap in Denis' filmography. Every performance is spectacular. It is honestly baffling that Hugh Jackman was not nominated for the oscar for best actor. Another great factor of this movie is that my favorite DOP, Roger Deakins controls the movie with his gorgeous cinematography. A great plot twist as well. Has a very David finchery type movie. Overall a great addition in Denis' filmography, 9/10.
Great movie, kept me on the edge of my seat. Could NOT believe the ending.

When I was about to watch Prisoners I thought that this would be an another "kidnapping" movie. I was in some aspects right, but the way this film was handled was done beautifully. It really reminded me of Zodiac, but to be fair I think this movie was better. Roger Deakins doesn't stop impressing me with his original cinematography techniques. Hugh Jackman really portrays a broken man with his raw "wolverine" style of acting.

Deserving of status at least as high as David Fincher's Se7en. Probably better. Villeneuve is an absolutely stellar director here with the perfect cast. Simultaneously a meditation on the moral ambiguity of torture and what it means to have belief in God and compassion. This is a masterpiece of filmmaking.
From its stirring performances to its intricate plot, this mystery-thriller has all the makings of a great movie.

A tense and captivating plot which is brought to life by the fantastic acting of Jackman and Gyllenhaal in particular. This is not your bog standard 'child goes missing and Dad take desperate measures' movie, it is much more than that and actually poses a number of difficult moral questions to the audience. A great film from start to the very well thought through finish.
Despite its lack of due process and drawn out narrative, this crime drama is compelling. Thanks John for the recommendation!

I absolutely loved this movie. Definitely 100%. Other than Logan (2016), this is Hugh Jackman's best performance. Jake Gyllenhaal was also spectacular and the score was breathtaking. This movie knows exactly what it is, I doesn't hesitate to tell the audience. I highly recommend this movie!

A modern, dark and thrilling tale, perfectly creates tension through both story and dialogue. This film is a masterpiece and a memorable watch.
A well crafted piece that continually pushes the audience to question what they would do in such a situation all while compelling them to become more drawn into a solid mystery.

Hugh Jackman gives one of his best performances ever and Jake Gyllenhaal is always amazing. This is a super well acted movie and definitely needs to be talked about more.

This movie is in the same league as Silence of the Lambs, Seven, and Psycho. It takes entertainment into a dark corner where very few films go to, that turns typical mainstream crime thrillers into something kind of special.Through Villeneuve's masterful direction, this film basically becomes a parent's worst nightmare. It gives you everything that you can want in a dark crime thriller: Complex heroes, haunting atmosphere, skin crawling suspense, and a mystery with so many twists and turns. This is the movie that made me realize Hugh Jackman can basically do any role and this is probably one of Gyllenhaal's top 3 best performances. If you're into detective movies that make your skin crawl then definitely check it out.

Relentlessly malevolent (and probably not the picture to watch if you are the parent of small ones), this thriller nevertheless shows director Denis Villeneuve's talent at building and sustaining tension while abiding by the audience's expectations. Two families see their youngest members abducted on Thanksgiving and Jake Gyllenhaal is the police detective assigned to find the abductor and get them back.  I haven't seen Taken or its sequels, so I'm not sure how this fits into the apparent genre - but parent Hugh Jackman decides to take the investigation into his own hands and his fury means that he isn't subtle.  I don't think we are meant to identify with Jackman, because everything he does seems to alienate the viewer (and threaten his relationships with everyone else, including his wife, Maria Bello, and the other couple, Viola Davis and Terrence Howard).  As the hunt for the abductor continues, the clues pile up, suspects are tracked down, creepiness abounds (and tends to dominate over the sadness and disgust that would otherwise be the main feeling, since we are dealing with child abduction and possible paedophilia here).  You might catch a bit of a Silence of the Lambs vibe, I suppose.  Gyllenhaal is dogged in his pursuit of all leads, although the police action is pretty genre-consistent at best. In the end, things do get tied up with a bow, but I've read that an even darker ending was proposed - that probably would have made for a better film.

Prisoners is a powerful story built around a father trying to be the best father he can be, by doing everything he can to save his daughter. What makes this a non-cliche movie is that law enforcement comes into play (with wonderful acting by Jake Gyllenhaal) to uncover more secrets that Mr. Dover cannot figure out on his own on what happened to his daughter. This ends up working out very well in the end. It kept me on the edge of my seat! Praise the filmmakers for making such an awesome movie.

Mature, dark, gritty, complex, profound and horrifyingly graphic, Hugh Jackman and Jake Gylenhaal showcase the best of their respective acting abilities by portraying a brilliantly disturbing contrast between two men who make very different choices. 

The film brilliantly succeeds at being both emotionally draining and unpredictable. It's message about the consequences of sacrificing morals for a justifiable cause are both haunting and deeply disturbing, and the sheer amount of pure emotion the characters are put through will have audience members in tears by the end of the movie.

However, it is not for the weak of stomach or heart.

Brilliant film was kept enthralled throughout hugh jackman at his best and jake gyllenhaal (who i'm not usually fan of) played his part so well, only thing I felt was a let down was the end however the film overall was excellent.

The plot of this movie is everything which couldn't get any better. Both lead actors's characters really fit into the story, the realistic touch really makes this movie amazing. 
Jake Gyllenhaal is oscar worhy.

SCOTT: (Dr. Scott Allison, Professor of Psychology, University of Richmond) Greg, it looks like Hugh Jackman has temporarily discarded his Wolverine costume just long enough to take on a new role as a desperate father.

GREG: (Greg Smith, Founder of Agile Writers of Richmond, VA) Yes he has and he s pretty convincing in the role.

SCOTT: Prisoners opens with two families sharing a Thanksgiving dinner together. We meet Keller and Grace Dover (Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello) along with their teenage son Ralph (Dylan Minnette) and their six-year-old daughter Anna (Erin Gerasimovich).  And we also meet Franklin and Nancy Birth (Terrence Howard and Viola Davis) and their young daughter Joy (Kyla Drew Simmons).  After their dinner, the families discover that the two young girls are missing. Ralph remembers that the girls had earlier been interested in playing on an RV parked near their home, and soon the police, led by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) focus their search on the RV and its owners.

GREG: Loki finds the RV and its driver is Alex (Paul Dano) who is a full grown adult but has the mental capacity of a 10-year-old. He is taken into custody but offers no clue as to the whereabouts of the girls. Also, there is no evidence of the girls in the RV. The police let him go. But Keller Dover is not convinced that Alex is ignorant of the girls  location and abducts the man. Together with his friend Franklin he hides the man in an abandoned home and beats him mercilessly trying to get some clue about where to find his daughter.

SCOTT: I ll cut right to the chase. Prisoners is one of the best movies of the year. The film grabbed my attention from the opening minute and held it in earnest for 2 and a half hours. Prisoners is the most compelling movie I ve seen since The Girl With the Dragon Tattoo which came out in 2011. What explains the excellence of Prisoners?  For one thing, it s riveting. We have a powerful storyline combined with the emotional anguish associated with innocent children gone missing. We witness the parallel hero journeys of two strong characters in Keller and Loki, each driven by the same goal of finding the missing girls alive yet they find themselves locking horns repeatedly. There are strong performances from the entire cast and some outstanding direction, too.

GREG: I have to agree. I was leary of a 150-minute running time, but every minute is put to good use. Detective Loki is not just dedicated, but obsessed with finding the girls. He hasn t lost a case yet and he doesn t expect to lose this one.  Despite Gyllenhaal s cool exterior, his Loki is focused and intense. There is also a time limit. Keller keeps reminding Loki that children that aren t found after 7 days are rarely found alive, if they are found at all. And the days tick by with both men approaching the search in their own fashion. Loki is methodical. We get the sense that his every waking moment is focused on solving this case. We are drawn into Loki s world and his intensity is palpable.

SCOTT: Whereas Loki is caught between his incompetent boss and Keller s defiance, Keller is torn between his Christian faith and his desire to do whatever it takes to get Alex to talk.  This makes for a terrific hero story, as Keller s intensity and devotion to his daughter s safety compromise his better judgment.  Or so it seems.  Keller cannot find it in himself to live up to his own strong Christian belief in forgiveness, and yet in an interesting twist, Keller s inability to forgive Alex leads him toward discovering the truth. One of many things I liked about Prisoners is the way it invites us to ponder interesting issues like forgiveness.  Another theme is the idea of  readiness  for life s obstacles. Keller believes he is physically and emotionally ready for any catastrophe, and he even drills this principle to his children, but it s painfully clear that Keller isn t ready at all for what unfolds in this movie. We learn that no one can be ready for every possible setback that life throws at us.

GREG: The title of the movie is misleading. We re attracted to the movie because we think that the story is about two little girls who are prisoners. But in fact, the prisoners in this film are Loki and Keller. They re both bound to their ideals and constrained by their beliefs. Loki believes that if he follows the clues and plays within the rules then he will solve the case. And he is trapped in that belief system. When things don t work the way he thinks they should, he begins to make mistakes. But working outside the box means the system doesn t work - and he needs it to work. Keller believes that protecting his family is his sole responsibility. And it s clear that he s not able to protect his family from every eventuality. If he cannot find his daughter he will have to live with the fact that he has failed. And this is not something he can live with. This forces him to work outside the system and find his daughter by any means necessary.

SCOTT: Well said, Greg. Prisoners is one of the year s best films and contains more memorable scenes than the previous dozen movies combined which we ve reviewed. This film is a great reminder of why I love movies and how a good story can leave its audience thinking and feeling in meaningful ways. I give Prisoners 5 Reels out of 5. The parallel hero stories here were also inspired and moving. Keller and Loki are most certainly not your Hollywood-stereotypical father and cop characters, nor were their journeys predictable. They were two highly memorable characters who travel the hero arc in surprising and powerful ways. There is absolutely no chance at all that their searing experiences could fail to transform them.  I give them 5 Heroes out of 5. Movie:   Hero: 

GREG: I agree, this is one of the best films of the year so far. I have to say that I didn t find it as rewarding as you did. I was held captive by the plot and the performances. But I wasn t satisfied that either man impacted the other. At the end of the day they were both vindicated in their own way of thinking. I don t think Detective Loki was much changed at the end of the film compared to the beginning. In fact almost nobody was much different at the end of the film. Keller was tortured by the fact that he couldn t keep his family safe from every evil thing and he became something that was far from heroic. I award Prisoners 4 Reels out of 5 for an entrancing psychological thriller and 4 out of 5 Heroes for compelling characters that kept me watching. To get to a higher rating I would want to see some interaction between Keller and Loki that would catalyze them to change in some more compelling way. Movie:  Hero:

Prisoners will be a tough watch for most. Physically and emotionally draining (in all the right ways). A fantastic psychological spin on a classic abduction story, with great performances all around the board. Disturbing and heart breaking, it will get audiences questioning their own morality.

Prisoners is a hard-hitting thriller that delivers gut-wrenching tension elevated by Oscar-worthy performances from both Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal. 

Packed with masterful cinematography, every frame of the film is a photograph.

However the film is let down by it's often predictable narrative, slow pace and dreadfully long runtime (153 minutes).

All-in-all: Denis Villeneuve gave us all a lesson in how to direct tension.
7.8/10

There is no doubt that Denis Villeneuve has what it takes to make a brilliantly shot film but what really makes this thriller great is the performance of the two leads: a twitchy and ruthless detective played by Jake Gyllenhaal and a grief stricken and relentless father played by Hugh Jackman.
Prisioners does everything right, has a good story, great performances and a first class director. But, the film doesn´t get you in the edge of your sit, at any point

This film was very well done. It was magnificent. Prisoners is a child abduction thriller about two girls who are abducted in broad daylight. The father of one of the girls won't stop at nothing to figure out what happened to his daughter. Hugh Jackman was excellent as the father trying to figure out where his daughter and her friend are. His performance was so believable. Jake Gyllenhaal did excellent as a detective trying to help the family and figure out the mystery. The rest of the cast were believable, including Viola Davis, Paul Dano, Dylan Minnette, and Terrence Howard. The cinematography was great. Denis Villeneuve is a visionary director who knows how to tell a story. The film was very emotionally tense. It's an Emotional Roller Coaster of a film. This is one of those films that makes you imagine what you would do in the situation, how far you would go to find your child. This film is a spectacular masterpiece. I would super recommend this film to everyone.

WHAT I LIKED: In some moments, 'Prisoners' is one of the grittiest, most frightening psychological thrillers I've ever seen, as it hooks you and places you in one of the most desperate and difficult scenarios imaginable. What hooks you though is a whole combination of incredible performances (particularly from Hugh Jackman), great character-building and typically cold, sparse and nail-biting direction from Denis Villenueve, and amazingly moody cinematography from Roger Deakins.
WHAT I DIDN'T LIKE: As it unravels, you realise the plot and themes are actually rather convoluted and silly, and the fact you get so much breathing room to think about all that makes it quite a big problem.
VERDICT: A dark, scary thriller where the brilliant cast and direction can't quite overcome the weaker foundations.

Brilliantly acted by Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal and directed by Denis Villeneuve, this is an amazing movie with a very tough plot, very hard to watch. You need stomach to handled everything that those parents suffer.
Prisoners puts quite a few balls in the air and it drops a few of them, but it's still a solid genre film.

"Prisoners" is a dark and grim tragedy that will keep tensions high and hearts hurting. 

When a child goes missing, Detective Loki takes on the case for this respective family. In a grueling and long, seemingly endless mystery, we'll experience the pain of losing a child and just how far one will go to put things back to normal.

"Prisoners" is an emotional and tragic story about a pair of families who lose their young daughters. Not only is this just hard to watch at times, but it's also really painful. This film is emotional and it just drains you. You're watching this family experience this loss and there's really no words to describe it. I don't think anyone would know what to do when it comes to losing their child and I can't imagine experiencing that. Seeing it play out is enough for me.

This film is a really good, intriguing mystery film. It's a mix between like a crime and a drama film because you're going along this journey with the detective to figure out who committed the crime, but you're also following the family's story. This movie keeps you guessing and wondering and it never really has a clear cut answer. It's very dark and the entire mystery somehow constantly added more and more layers to the story. It was a very fun (I use that term loosely) story to try and analyze and solve.

Hugh Jackman has an amazing and gut wrenching performance here. You see just how far a Father will go to find his daughter and the surplus amount of pain that comes with that. He does things and experiences things that most other men won't, all because this is such a painful tragedy. Jake Gyllenhaal, who's still my favorite actor today, also gives a great performance. He plays the serious and firm detective with a twitch, and he also does a great job as one of the primary leads. Paul Dano also gives one of his eeriest performances to date, playing a low IQ, potential suspect boy. All the performances were fantastic in this film and they really brought out that emotional gravity of the situation.

The screenplay overall was amazing. I loved the dialogue and the chain of events. This is a long, drawn out film that might not necessarily be for everyone, but it's still a fantastically structured script.

In the end, "Prisoners" is one of the best films of 2013, being one of the darkest and most real dramas out there.
For anyone looking for a great thriller/mystery/suspense film, this is it.

Prisoners is a very tense and disturbing journey through the eyes of a man blinded by revenge, Hugh Jackman's best performance, and a cop who desperately needs to get to the bottom of this investigation, as he has no prior success rate in his police work, which is such a driving factor in this film and creates such full-bodied character development. The cinematography is amazing and perfectly captures the reality and lack of hope surrounding the kidnapping. All of these reasons lead up to a surprisingly amazing film, leading me to give this a 9/10.

Prisoners is a story about two little girls gone missing and the drama and story behind it. Hugh Jackman, Terrance Howard, and Jake Gyllenhaal are in this as well as Voila Davis and other talented actors and actresses. First off let's talk about Jackman, the main character. OH MY GOD HES FUCKING AMAZING, seriously, I love x-men, but this might be his best performance and movie I've ever seen. Terrance Howard and Viola Davis, the other couple in the film with the missing daughter are both great here too. I was really blown away by Jake Gyllenhaal, playing the head detective to solve this case about the girls. Paul Dano plays the role he plays in almost every film, but with a little something extra, which made his character even more compelling. I could talk for hours about the acting, but all I can say now is that every character was extremely compelling and never bored me when I was watching. The camerawork and lighting are all impeccable as well, long drawn out shots are featured quite often, and it was a really good looking film. The plot and script are both excellent, fueled by perfect direction and an enormous effort by the actors, it is fully realized as the dark and unsettling narrative it is meant to be. The movie pulled my in from very early on, and refused to let me go with a tightly written plot and the insane turns made not only by the plot but also the characters in the movie. Each moment felt like time was evaporating from the characters hands and as they desperately did anything they could to find answers, I found out that maybe the good guys weren't all that different from the bad guys. Fully realized characters through magnificent acting (espically by Jackman) made me feel and understand each decision they made, no matter how unsettling it was. This is a hard movie to watch, such like 12 Years a Slave, you don't really agree with what's happening, but the film is so damn good you can't look away from it. In the end, Prisoners is in my opinion one of the best films ever made, it is extremely under viewed but those who have seen it have witnessed a masterpiece in film and hopefully appreciated if at least half as much as I do

Story/Screenplay: (3.5/5) A strong crime drama for the first half, then slipped a bit by its end.  Too bad, it was looking like a big winner.

Duration/Tempo: (3/5) At 2 hours and 33 minutes, it's a very, very long movie that felt long.  It was moving quickly for a while, then slowed at the same time the story started to drop off.

Cast & Crew: (4.5/5) Kudos to Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal for excellent performances, and to Paul Dano for a lesser role with minimal lines, yet he was effective.

Summary: (4/5) The film was long and felt like it, especially towards the end.  However, the story was good and the cast was excellent.  Overall, a thumbs up.

A grimly dark thriller that's ostensibly about the abduction of two young girls. In a chilling opening sequence they disappear after a Thanksgiving dinner from their utterly normal suburban street.

Ultimately, the film is about what's legitimate in a civilised society. Hugh Jackman is fantastic as Keller Dover, the father of one of the girls, who very quickly takes the law into his own hands, and will stop at seemingly nothing, acting purely on hunches and his own prejudices. 

My concern about the film's own prejudices is that he's portrayed mostly as the protagonist, the character with all the agency, whereas Terrence Howard  (his friend and father of the other missing girl) is conflicted, struck with deference to the law and the authorities, rendered helpless by liberal angst and weak where Keller is strong and decisive. The film also renders their wives mostly useless. Hmmm...

Between them and the horror of their missing children is Jake Gyllenhaal, excellent in one of his 'quiet' performances. 

It's true that there's little triumphalism on display in the finale, there's no great redemption or satisfaction to be had from Keller's vigilante approach.

This is a film of no little skill - the cinematography and direction is terrific, and it's shot through with unease. But it does seem to be taking itself VERY seriously, and this grim intensity is pretty wearing by the end.

Let's just get this out of the way. Jake Gyllenhaal is one of the greatest actors of all time, and always delivers a phenomenal performance.

This whole movie is so intense, that you are on the edge of your seat. The mystery is very intriguing, and you are figuring it out along the way, and enjoying yourself doing so. It is also filled with, not just excellent performances, but very powerful ones as well. And the writing is just so great. It has a great story, with a great ending, and the dialogue is excellent and keeps you interested. It has phenomenal cinematography, and is excellently directed by Denis Villenueve. This whole movie is brilliantly dark and intense, and has excellent performances, direction, cinematography, and writing.

Outstanding acting, a tight, mesmerizing and engaging script and the directing make this one of the most exciting and best thrillers of recent years. The themes and questions raised here together with the images stay with you for a very long time. A gem of the genre.

Prisoners is the most tightly plotted 153-minute movie you'll ever see. It's a masterpiece of the crime genre that covers a lot of ground, but every crumb, clue, and detail dropped by director Denis Villeneuve and screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski is essential to its (murky-ish) resolution. Comparisons to films like Se7en and Zodiac are inevitable because of the films' shared genre and dark look/tone. Prisoners, however, is a different beast entirely. Not only is it a step up in terms of quality (yep), but it packs an emotional punch throughout that's tough to sit with and damn near impossible to shake. It's the perfect way to kick off the fall movie season and a definite contender for my best film of 2013.

It's Thanksgiving in rural Pennsylvania, and Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) and his family are spending the holiday with their close friends and neighbors, the Birches. When the youngest of both clans, Anna Dover (Erin Gerasimovich) and Joy Birch (Kyla Drew Simmons) run off to play, there's nothing on their parents' mind other than leftovers, but when they don't turn up and can't be found anywhere, everyone understandably panics.

The police, led by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal), pick up the primary suspect rather quickly. The girls were seen playing near an RV that's owned by Alex Jones (Paul Dano), and when Loki moves in on him, he tries to get away. Unfortunately, they can't charge him with anything after a forensic sweep of the RV turns up nothing, but that's not good enough for Keller. He grabs Alex outside of the home where he lives with his Aunt Holly (Melissa Leo), and with the help of Joy's father, Franklin (Terrence Howard), he chains Alex up at a run-down property he owns and starts torturing him for information. If the police won't do anything, he's prepared to take matters into his own hands.

That's just Prisoners' first 30 minutes or so. It ultimately follows a remarkable number of threads-each one darker than the last-before the whole tale is told. Villeneuve, making his English-language debut following the searing drama Incendies, teases each thread in such a way that you know it will be integral to the story as a whole. You know this because you've seen this movie before. It's a crime film that's built knowing decades of genre conventions exist and will be necessarily followed if we're to travel from point A to point B successfully. But Prisoners overcomes the trappings of feeling overly familiar by paying attention to detail and keeping every ball in the air-something studio thrillers just can't pull off (or don't care to try pulling off) today.

Prisoners' supremely rich character work is another essential aspect to its success. The detective character is a critical piece in this genre's puzzle, but Loki is a very special iteration of someone who's typically one-note and uninteresting. In the hands of a never-better Jake Gyllenhaal, the detective takes on a fascinating hybrid of vulnerability and hard-nosed cleverness. He figures stuff out, but he's often behind the 8-ball (sometimes tragically so). And on occasion, the trail's-gone-cold nature of the case manifests itself outwardly through Loki in dangerous ways. It's a brilliant performance.

The whole ensemble is terrific, really, with Hugh Jackman doing career-best work as an already intense father upping the intensity to a 15 out of 10 following the disappearance of his daughter. Paul Dano doesn't say much, but his creepy and pathetic (yet bizarrely sympathetic) portrayal of Alex fits the film perfectly. Melissa Leo is so out-there playing Alex's aunt, but like Dano, she's absolutely magnetic. Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello and others complete the deep principal cast, and all excel in smaller roles.

The film is a spectacular editing showcase, and Roger Deakins' dark, small-town-influenced cinematography is among the year's best. And Villeneuve and Guzikowski-not content to simply satisfy their audience on a visceral level-touch on religion and rural American values in interesting and non-judgemental ways. Simply put, Prisoners is a one-of-a-kind movie-something that's as thought-provoking as it is emotionally involving, as well-acted as it is well-crafted, and as good as anything else this year.

Denis Villeneuve's Prisoners, is a haunting, sometimes disturbing, but ultra-compelling suspense thriller that is undoubtably the best film of 2013. Prisoners is a film directed by Denis Villeneuve and is about a kidnapping instance that has occurred in this small town and behind the investigation is some of my favorites, Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman. I absolutely loved this movie. Villeneuve's story telling mixed with a blend of intense suspense, drama, and emotion, perfectly accommodates a beautiful mystery thriller. Hugh Jackman in the film plays one of the main dads whose girl has gone missing. This is by far the best we've seen of him in awhile because his performance is top notch. Jackman gives an excellent portrayal of a father going insane and that will do literally anything to get his daughter back. Gyllenhaal just gets better as he keeps making movies. There is no role this guy can not do and it is a true pleasure watching this man act. After viewing Prisoners, the film will definitely leave an emotional scar on you. Villeneuve is afraid to expose his dark side. He takes this movie as far as it gets on the creepy aspect and will send you chills throughout the whole the movie. The film is two and a half hours long but don't let the run time scare you. Prisoners' mysterious plot will have your eyes and ears glued to the screen listening to every tiny little detail because being extremely attentive while watching this movie is very important.    I also enjoyed the setting of the film and the way it looked on screen. The cold environment added to the chilling aspect even more. Prisoners will haunt you with its eerie story but will leave you utterly impressed with its heart racing storyline.

The plot is complicated yet followable, the acting is good, the baddies are weird yet feasible and the movie is gripping throughout.  The fashionable mumbling style of acting, which makes some of the dialogue difficult to follow and the ridiculously reckless drive to the hospital are my only criticisms: they didn't retract from my enjoyment of the film though.  This a film with a difference.  Watch it and it's very unlikely you'll be disappointed.

As of now this is the best directed film of Denis Villeneuve. Prisoners makes your eyes glued to the screen, the characters are well written, the pacing is perfect, the story is magnificent and the twist in the finale blew me away like I did not see that coming. I forgot to mention how beautiful the cinematography is thanks to Roger Deakins. If you haven't seen Prisoners then you are in for a ride.

This may sound obvious or trite, but it truly is a parent's worst nightmare: Your child just disappears, suddenly and without a trace. That's the scenario in the crime drama/thriller "Prisoners" (R, 2:33).

When the young daughters of two neighbors go out to play after their families share Thanksgiving dinner together and then no one can find the girls, the panic is immediate and gut-wrenching.  The helplessness of these two sets of parents (Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello as Keller and Grace Dover and Terrence Howard and Viola Davis as Franklin and Nancy Birch) is compounded when the police release a person of interest named Alex Jones (played brilliantly by Paul Dano) for lack of evidence.  Despite the fact that Alex has the mental capacity of a 10-year-old, Keller is convinced that Alex knows something. He takes matters into his own hands and goes much farther than even the most devoted of parents could imagine.  Keller is willing to do anything, and I mean ANYTHING, to extract the information he needs to find these two little girls. Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) is doing what he can to solve the case, and even seems willing to go a little outside the law to do it, but keeps coming up empty.

The tension gradually but steadily builds as these parents know that time is running out for their missing children. Clues in the case are scant and hints as to where this story is going are there on the screen, but seem too trivial to matter - until they do. The plot twists and ultimate reveals are shocking, but the film's real power is in the questions it forces us to ask - and keep asking after the film is over. The script is smart enough to provide us sufficient closure to justify the emotional investment we've made in this story, but still leaves it open-ended enough to give us something to think about after the credits roll. The unusually long run time may make you feel like a prisoner, but the complex, well-directed and very well-acted story (mostly) justifies the film's length. "B+"

A hard and dark thriller set in chilling northern part of U.S during winter. Really sets the underlying dark tone of this kidnapping of two minor girls. A restless angry and upset father (Hugh Jackman) don't take no for an answear. And a 100% clearance cop (Jake Gyllenhal) does a brilliant subtle role, with lots of depth and mystique. The plot is filled with puzzles and creeps under your skin as it's highly realistic and tensional. Gonna throw myself over Villeneuve's catalogue.
A very powerful and rich mystery/drama. Everything is quality.
Great build up to a so so unravel and ending. The actors and cinematography are on point as is the disturbing tone, but certain aspects could've been handled better.
Perfect cast and acting plus a hint of gore = PRISONERS.

Prisoners has devastating anxiety and building suspense. A masterclass, the kind Hitchcock would be proud off. The story, the acting and the camera work surprise me with how good there are. Also, there are interesting religious undertones.

Disturbing and tough to watch but emotionally powerful and important, Prisoners is a tough as nails thriller (more like a horror in some cases) that is powerfully acted by everyone and offers a roller coaster of twists that you never see coming.
Asks the question of how far you are willing to go to save your loved ones. Jackmans best performance since the Prestige.

Everything about Prisoners from it's acting to it's gorgeous cinematography, excellent pacing, intriguing writing and fabulous directing makes Prisoners one of my all time favorites. But I don't recommend parents watch it with their kids.
While the plot somewhat leaves a bit to be desired it's a thoughtfull and emotional film, featuring one hell of a performance from Hugh Jackman and a look that's both absorbing and disturbing.

Hugh Jackman has a really great performance in this. Bolstered by a solid performance from Gyllenhaal and quality directing. This movie had me on the edge of my seat pretty much the whole time I was watching it.

I loved this movie, it was an interesting story told very well, i
didn't even notice the long run time and that's always a very good
sign. The acting was brilliant from everyone involved especially Jake,
he just gets better and better. I solved the mystery so nothing came as
a great shock but i still had a great time waiting to see if i was
right and i felt very smart when i had guessed correctly, as i thought
the film was very clever. The style of the movie was superb, it was
very atmospheric and it was extremely tense to watch, i was on edge the
whole way through. My only regret is that i took so long to watch it. I
would definitely watch it again.

Full review at WordsonFilms.com 

While it's not quite as good as "Enemy," Prisoners is a solid and thought-provoking thriller that features strong performances and offers plenty of suspense. At the same time, the film is simply not as good as it should have been; as good as the bulk of it is, it does not entirely live up to its full potential.
Frustrating at times, but for some that may be a good thing. With that in mind, "Prisoners" is still a beautifully shot and strongly acted thriller that makes for a haunting experience.

My favorite description of this movie comes via YMS who called it "By the book but better". I couldn't have described it better than that myself, so I won't really try to. Jackman and Gyllenhaal were both huge oscar snubs, surprising even more so based on the time of year it came out. The cinematography by Deakins mixed with Villeneuve's direction are eye catching. Especially in the driving scene in the third act (which I'll leave as vague as possible to avoid spoilers.) Overall, fans of the Crime/Thriller genre will love this, but those who find it underwhelming might recognize it as better than your average, but there's nothing new here to hook them.
Very suspenseful film.
Riveting From the start! Great acting all the way around and the ending was surprising. Great Film..Well Done...
This movie and it's outcome will resonate me for a long time. Excellent in every department.
Prisoners was a highly unexpected masterpiece. Beautifully acted by both Jackman and Gyllenhaal, Prisoners is dark, grim and gripping from start to finish.
Despite predicting part of the finale, the execution was done excellently.

Real crazy ride of a detective movie, way beyond what I expected.  Haven't seen Gone Girl yet, but I've seen Gone Baby Gone and this seems above that of what it ha to offer.  The story was compelling and always had a new turn, often for the worst for the characters, but great for the film.  The acting and script are fantastic, in particular Hugh does a great job all the time as the stressed, no sleep, good guy doing terrible things in order to save his daughters life.  Everything is bleak, and when they discover something to seems to look up, only to be crushed again.  It's a great story from beginning to end, always has our attention, but the second half really takes off by being intense not because of shootouts or fighting but with how well what is going on is portrayed, plus how realistic and terrible the things that are going on are.  From being shot, to suicid, to the discovery of cloths, and the torture of those who can't physically save themselves.  It's a roller-coaster watch and amazingly well done, there's simply nothing that was done wrong.  Would 10/10 recommend, probably over Gone Baby Gone but would have to watch it again to know for sure.

An incredibly well directed film, with a powerful central performance from Hugh Jackman and a story that surely will have you at the edge of your seat. That also features amazing cinematography from Roger Deakins and strong performances from the rest of the cast.
Lots of violence (sometimes shockingly so) but there was still more to it and I was captivated by this thriller for the whole 2h and 33 min,

Prisoners is a dark and disturbing movie, but overall compelling. The acting is spot on, the plot is strange and interesting, and it is all executed well. It is a very long movie but I was never bored or edgy. Although there is some movies that have a similar premise, "Prisoners" brings it's own gritty and realistic view. It is one of the best movies of 2013.
amazing performances throughout, and what Hugh Jackman brings to this movie is simply beautiful.

A grim and quite realistic interpretation of a sudden disturbance happening in small town life.
Prisoners is a gripping thriller that delivers an intense atmosphere leaving the outcome of the film unpredictable. The acts of some of the townsfolk to preserve their outward sanity fall into the realm of the grotesque. 
The leaders of the magnificent cast are Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal. Their presence adds another complex and emotional layer to an already nail-biting scenario. They represent different sides of justice- one abiding the written laws and the other following the individual's morality, the detective and the tormented father. When the forces meet picking a side is nearly impossible. 
Interrogations, brutal acceptances, unexpected twists, all of them crack the boundaries of psychological warfare thus making Prisoners a certainly worth while spectacle.
an entirely outstanding thriller which keeps u mentaly present throughout
GRIPPING | INTENSE | OVERBLOATED | SPELLBINDING (92-out-of-100)
Exceptional. One of the most intense, emotional films I've seen. The irony of life well demonstrated in this story.
Intense and at times hard to watch, Prisoners' great actors and talented director makes you forgive the terribly lame end. Still worth it

Director, Denis Villeneuve (Enemy, Sicario, Arrival) has an amazing sense of direction, and imagination. Loved this movie, amazing work of art! Also, cinematographer, Roger Deakins, spectacular job for giving the film an eerie vibe. 5/5 stars!

So good! Movie scenes are breathtaking and the scenery went with movie, everything about this movie was perfect! Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal did amazing.

Depths of humanity, passion, insanity, reason vs delusion, the quest for truth, the longing for relief of a heart in anguish. How far would you go?
This was brilliant, full of emotion, but also disturbing. Deep, gripping, well acted, and artistically shot. Plus a homicide mystery. The twist wasn't as big a surprise as I thought, I kinda suspected. And I guess the last act was definitely the weakest. Like it turned into a cliche whodunnit.Too bad. 7.5/10

Really intense and well done thriller. One of the few in the last years with great performances by Jackman, Gyllenhaal and Dano.
It also has some content to chew. I really enjoyed watching it.

Psychologically unnerving and uncomfortably graphic, Prisoners takes the general nightmare of a parent's worst fear and remolds it into something profound and skin-crawling, all while demanding the strongest and most committed efforts from Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal.

Watching Prisoners is like solving a puzzle and/or answering a riddle that has a mystery answer that you keep on guessing. This is the main strength of the film. Its mystery and thriller theme acts as its grip to the audience to keep them interested and glued to it until the conclusion of its puzzling mystery. Though, some of the scenes with numerous dialogues were quite boring plus it runs more than two hours, I can still say it is entertaining and worth my time. I just feel that the conclusion is so open-ended because the movie left it to the imagination of the audience for the answer. Prisoners is a 2013 thriller film that focuses on abduction of two young girls in Pennsylvania and how far a parent would go just to protect his family.
Gyllenhaal and Jackman have created a film that is absolutely captivating. I find new things to love about this movie every time I watch it. In my opinion, Gyllenhaal's best performance.

The best crime drama up to date since "The Place Beyond The Pines". Perfect 5 for me.
This isn't just possibly Hugh Jackman's best performance, it's quite possibly one of the best performances I've ever seen
This movie was unpredictable. Kept me guessing. Thought-provoking. Suspenseful and a great mystery. I recommend this movie!

Canadian Denis Villenuive is on a role. Two films in one year, both excellent and now he's directing Blade Runner 2. Prisoners is a superb thriller that captures empathetic characters, a gripping storyline and a pitch-perfect ending. There is never a false note and the film doesn't feel "Hollywood" for a second. Jackman's performance is memorably intense and the audience is left thinking what's right and what's wrong. It is not just about a prisoner but rather about how we are all prisoners of our own minds and perceptions.
Excellent acting and cinematography!!! A tension filled drama but sometimes wonders off but fortunately not too much.  Excellent ending!!!!
A real dark suspense thriller which goes deep in your soul. An A-Listers performance from Jake and Hugh.

A nail biting suspense/thriller driven by incredible performances from Jackman and Gyllenhaal. Jackman leads the true performance as a dad who will stop at nothing for his child, but Gyllenhaal's character is underutilized. I would've loved to see more of the story behind Gyllenhaal's character as it seems so much mast have gone into his background in making him what he is, but we only get a taste from what we get of him in the film. Even though I believe that could've improved the film, this is a great film. (86%)

Prisoners is an emotional film about the loss of principles and the line between good and bad, conscious evil and subconscious evil. It attempts to portray the police force as perceptive, diligent, and objective, however, if anything, they appear to be incompetent and useless. The two power actors; Jackman and Gyllenhaal, are wonderful in their on-screen chemistry. They work together and against each other, and with the help of Villeneuve with his pan-out technique, they deliver an end that is the best end possible with the tools at hand. There are frustrating moments, and there are plot holes that make the police to be glaringly incompetent, but the movie holds its own, seeming slightly better than the average missing persons drama film.

Probably the best movie of 2013. I'm just gonna put that out there before I begin my review. This movie is perfect. It is perfect. Prisoners is about two family friends having a get together when their girls both go missing. This film is so realistically scary and very real. It truly captures how people would act when put under pressure. Everyone in this movie is amazing. Not a single performance that I thought could've been better. The movie has a very dark and creepy vibe throughout the whole movie and keeps you guessing throughout. The twist is very satisfying and it makes sense. This movie has a great cast and a great script. Prisoners is probably the best movie of 2013. I had only one problem with the movie. The ending. At first, when the ending came, it felt rushed and abrupt, it didn't make sense. After the movie was done, it had me thinking a while. After a while of thinking, it clicked. The ending isn't a big problem but it felt like the movie just ended. You have to think for a while to really find the true meaning of the ending. Other than that, this is a PERFECT film that I highly encourage you to check this one out in theaters. 

Prisoners: 5/5 stars

This is easily one of my favorite suspense thrillers. Villenueve knows how make sure that the audience will keep their eyes on the movie. He made sure that the plot came full circle and it did wonderfully.

Riveting, intense and suspenseful. Jake Gyllenhaal and Hugh Jackman give powerhouse performances in this terrifying film. You never wanna take your eyes off the screen. There is not one moment wasted in Prisoners, this is definition of a masterpiece film.
Every parents worst nightmare brought to life in this creepy thriller. Some well placed twists keep it gripping until the final frame.
Absolutely gripping! Keeps you literally on the edge of your seat. Terrific acting and smart writing make this movie tick from start to finish.

Prisoners 

Prisoners is a crime thriller which will keep you entertained throughout the movie. If you like great acting and an interesting story this movie is for you. The plot is When Keller Dover's daughter and her friend go missing, he takes matters into his own hands as the police pursue multiple leads and the pressure mounts. I thought this film was great even though it was slow at times. I enjoyed the acting, It also was a real emotional movie, It was not predictable, and it was not a confusing movie and it was very original

What he did different was the good guy became a bad guy by the end of the film. My favorite character though was Loki. He brang some much needed comic relief to a very depressing movie. 

I would give this film a 8.7 rating. There was great acting. I thought the movie was too long to tell the story effectively. I thought they could have ended the movie better. My ending would be Mr. Dover reuniting with his daughter and family. 

Overall i would recommend this movie to any Jake Gyllenhaal fan and any crime fans. Good overall movie.

a great who done it! Lots of theories come up along the way... hard to tell who it is until the end.

Great acting, interesting story, non-stop suspense and Jake Gyllenhaal is FINE!!

I'm not writing the overview that is readable elsewhere. This is a stunner of a horror film (kind of, because little girls, you know, are mandatory in horror and here we have two missing at once).  It is also a murder mystery and a police. Villeneuve does have the right touch. The whole is psychologically holding solid. Insanity is actually much more common than people think in general. When tested, psychological flaws and cracks start to show up. Everyone here has some. It makes for a very real feel of all the characters, rather well played btw. The viewer has the chance to try to guess who's who. Who's the killer and who are these suspicious characters? Probably like real police work, clues abound. Crimes abound. Could there be a connection between this and that? Is this a clue? Shouldn't the villain father see a clue instead of pummelling his first obvious suspect? It's amazing maze of a film to understand the value of a nudge and the power of quiet listening. All thumbs up!

3/19/2015: A pretty good drama with an interesting twist.

How far would you go to protect your family? Keller Dover (Hugh Jackman) is facing every parent's worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter, Anna, is missing, together with her young friend, Joy, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) arrests its driver, Alex Jones (Paul Dano), but a lack of evidence forces his release. As the police pursue multiple leads and pressure mounts, knowing his child's life is at stake the frantic Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. But just how far will this desperate father go to protect his family?... 

The topic of "Prisoners" is without no doubt one of the more difficult things a human being can go through. A missing child and when minutes turns into hours into days every second is valuable. There´s an emotional complexity in the film and the sense of dread/something terrifying lurking in the darkness is so apparent you can touch it. Denis Villenueve has managed to put together this strong movie without losing the focus of the topic and getting the absolutely best out of every actor/actress in the film. Hugh Jackman is magnificent (one of his best performances showing all the emotional states you can imagine), Paul Dano is great as the pacified Alex and the same goes for Jake Gyllenhaal, Terence Howard, Maria Bello and Melissa Leo. I love the layers in the film and Villenueve keeps you in his grip until the end part in which you start to grasp the connecting dots before the conclusion. The weight in the movie lays on the male counterparts and all the females are less prominently in the film. This gives maybe a less balanced script, but it´s not stealing the focus of the film. "Prisoners" is truly engaging throughout the running time despite not maybe adding a revolutionary point of view on a classic theme.
It's a movie with unexpected twists and turns that draw you in!!!
Near perfect, on so many levels
Absolutely loved this.
Wow. Shockingly good.

A really great thriller with a brillant final. 
The performances of Gyllenhaal and Jackman are amazing.

Wow. This is one of the best mystery thrillers I've seen despite the whole sketchy white trash beginning. You have to follow it and it does not have a narrative guiding the viewer along or summing it up at the end with a nice bow so some might not pick up on everything. It does come full circle at the end and it fills the plot holes pretty much at the last minute then it rolls credits. I can usually pick up clues to how it will end and put together the maze right away but it didn't just end there..."hope for the best, prepare for the worst".  Like some other reviews I read it maintains enough plausibility to be believable that it could really happen or has happened and after it was over I just stared at the screen processing what I saw. Anyone who is a parent will find this especially difficult to watch because you keep thinking about what you would do- and how far you would go.  Would I become capable of things that happened in the chain of events if I thought I would get my girl back?  What if I never could get her back- would I recover?  Fantastic acting by Jackman- he had the stand out performance with of course Gyllenhaal at close second.  This one will stay in my collection and next time around I look forward to seeing what I may have missed now that I know how it ends.
A really good movie, completely worth a rewatch if I get around to it, a really well crafted story.
A very realistic and nerve-wracking piece of thrilling cinema. Jackman and Gyllenhaal are both superb. A must see.
Great movie, a little drawnout, two hours.

I was a bit disappointed. Many scenes were dragged out far longer than necessary. The clues seems so obvious, but took Gyllenhaal forever to figure out.   The resolution left me wanting more as well. This movie is on the cusp of being great, but falls short.

The last hour has you constantly guessing and some will miss the clues and red herrings throughout.  Also leaves  you shaken as a parent wondering "How far will u go?"

Overall, Prisoners is a great film and needs WAY more attention.
Not sure how people didn't like this movie. Great thriller

Phenomenal movie...best movie of the year to date.
this movie is good i love it!

Well acted, written, and directed. Perhaps Hugh Jackman's best performance. But to what end? Pitch black and disturbing, the film never really shows consequences to the actions of the main characters, thus rendering the film's central conceit - "What would you do?" - irrelevant. Awesome Movie! Excellent!!! A must watch film!! Really liked it!!! Great acting!!!

*Spoiler alert* The ending was dreadful. Incomplete story. Not even the sort of ending that "makes you wonder", it was just not finished. Almost like they ran out of money or time or somehting. I know they didn't but it's how it came off. The rest of the movie was fine. Good actors. Hugh Jackman could make any script look good though. 2 and a half stars. If they had finished the ending it might have been 4 stars.

As any parent, imagine your worst nightmare, imagine your child had been kidnapped from you in broad day light, with very little idea of who done it and a growing fear of as time goes by what you may find. Prisoners takes this idea and turns it into something totally raw, powerful and at some points extremely intense to watch. On thanksgiving day the Keller and Birch family unite to celebrate the festivities, in a small little town, in a small little street. With all the excitement going on, both families daughters, who are no older than 8, ask if its okay to head back to the Dover household, a 2 minute walk, to pick up a toy. After some ground rules are made off the children go and that is where it all goes horribly wrong. With nothing more to go on, than a dodgy looking RV parked on the street, the families turn frantic and soon enlist the help of Detective Loki, a left field cop, who has aced every assignment given to him. Soon suspects begin to come out the woodwork, leaving both families to do what they think is right for the good of their children. Looking at this cast, its hard to imagine the package you may receive here, not that they are bad, but there are some huge names in here, leaving you wondering how far the film will take it. All i'll say is do not worry, every single actor, minus a few stereotypically written lines or situations knock the entire piece into the stratosphere. Hugh Jackman, Maria Bello, Terrence Howard and Viola Davis are all on top form as the parents, the dynamic between them all is phenominal, ranging from Maria Bello's completely torn apart and useless wife to Hugh Jackman's fiery anger. Everyone here is really on fire. Loki is played outstandingly by Jake Gyllenhall, his mix of intensity and profesionalism, with added mannerisms, are a joy to watch. His performance is best served when dealing with Hugh Jackman or his captain, who wont stop riding his ass. Paul Dano and Melissa Leo put in a thunderous, performance as the main suspect and his aunt. Both of them go to such lengths to look and sound so different from their usual, your actually pleasantly surprised by the time you work out, who it is your actually watching add to this mix of powerhouse performances. Add to this some extremely creepy cinematography, harking back to John Carpenters Halloween, with slow tracking wide shots, that make everything seem voyouristic or long one takes, in particular a torture scene which literally looks like it was nailed in 1 take and your onto a winner. The entire town feels dank and winteresque, giving you this feeling of dread and hopelessness. The lighting is creepy and emotional and the grade on this thing is dulled down, to make it look less big budget and more real life. So whats wrong with the film? Well a couple of things, first off there are some pacing and editing issues. The film is over 2 and a half hours long, which is fine, but at points you literally feel like your backtracking in order to show how torturous this all is, half an hour could have easily been shaved off this and it would have been all the better for it. Also the film likes to fade to black just before major points of relieve happen, yet again, i get why this is done, at some points it works astoundingly well. But at points in treads on giving you no relieve what so ever, that you really aren't sure what the bigger picture is trying to be. Also the film spends a stupid amount of time of a drawing of a puzzle, only for it to turn into something so stupid and throwaway, had they actually done something intelligent with this, id have gladly sat an extra half hour i just wanted shaved off watching them add another thick layer onto the piece. finally the ending, I will not spoil it but its so off kilter that your left kind of buzzing about like a dying bee in the wind. Very little exposition is given to the final 15 minutes and because of this, you just feel like it was a ploy to turn one final twist on the audience. Other than that, this film is a thrilling and emotional, pitch black piece. I highly reccomend it.

Not so sure why so many have lambasted this as pulp trash; it makes some wrong turns toward the end but still has more depth and ambiguity (mostly in Hugh Jackson's character) than most films of its type.

It's hard to find mystery films that really grab you immediately. Prisoners plays with a lot of moral grey area, highlighted by possibly some of the best acting Hugh Jackman's ever done. The frustration and anger generated by the film is disconcerting and haunting.
This, was so good, I really have no clue what to say. The story twists, the acting, the script, everything. Hands down one of my new favorites.

/10

Prisoners is a well crafted, intense and unforgettable thriller with superb performances and the power to never let you stop watching. You get so invested with the situation and it makes you work like a detective, it will have you gasping for air.

The sign of a great film is one that might technically be long but doesn't feel long while watching it, that is because I was utterly absorbed by the characters and the plot. It is also well acted, love the cast, script is good, looks great and it has a gripping conclusion.
Grim, violent in places not so much an enjoyable watch but a cracking story.
Lots of suspense and very unsettling, exactly what you want from this kind of film. Excellent performances from all the actors.

The existential dread may prove too brutal off some. But the balance between phenomenal acting, strong writing and brilliant direction secures the film in a comfortable spot that out paces most crime thrillers of the last decade. For those who can handle.. Hold on; and enjoy.
Jackman and Gyllenhaal are as good as usual, but Prisoners disgusting attempt at modernizing redneck culture makes it a repulsive, awful film.

Have you ever considered what you would do, or how far you would go to protect your family? What could you be capable of doing to ensure the safety of your loved ones? Prisoners is a film that pushes the boundaries of moralistic values, it crosses a line that we hope to never have to cross in a situation we pray we never have to be in.
Keller Dover played by Hugh Jackman (Wolverine, Les Misérables) and his wife Grace played by Maria Bello(Payback, The Secret Window) attend a Thanksgiving dinner at the home of their neighbours Franklin played by Terrence Howard (Iron Man, Hustle & Flow) and Nancy Birch played by Viola Davis (How to get away with murder, The Help). Their 2 young daughters, Anna and Joy go outside to play but never return. An investigation is launched with Detective Loki played by Jake Gyllenhaal (Nightcrawler, Brokeback Mountain)arresting the prime suspect being a young man with the IQ of a ten year old whose RV was spotted where the young girls were last seen. As time drags on and the girls remain missing slowly desperation sets in and Keller decides to take matters into his own hands.... Once again I want to say so much about the plot but if I do I'd be breaking my own rules and giving away so much.
The plot is so interesting, I loved it, I loved the way the story in its entirety was played out, and I loved the characters and how well they were played. Hugh Jackman proves once again why he is so sought after in the film industry he was so convincing as the desperate father I'm surprised there was no Oscar buzz about his performance. Not only Hugh though, his fellow cast members were just as engaging and hypnotic. A perfect cast in my opinion. Jake Gyllenhaal (who did win Best Supporting Actor of the Year Award at the 2013 Hollywood Film Festival) was mesmerising with his character as well. The other stand out feature for me though was the cinematography it was amazing and really feel it helped the story teller tell his amazing tale; once again I was extremely impressed by the visuals. I don't really know the director Denis Villeneuve's other works but I can tell he is a man of talent and I'll be looking him up to see what else he has done.
Prisoners will leave you feeling desperate and curious, running at a little under 3hrs it does take its toll as well, I'm not sure it really needed to be that long but for the outcome it does work and you hardly notice the time. The film is very disturbing in nature, has some very graphic scenes so not one for the kids. Be prepared for a magical ride with this one it'll have you'll be running a full gauntlet of emotions and I'm so glad to say the twists and turns the film takes throughout only make it so much better.

Interesting movie, albeit with extremely dark overtones. There is a constant abandonment of certainty in the sense that the perpetrator of the kidnapping is completely elusive. Furthermore, Keller Dover pinpoints the alleged kidnapper and insists that the police take him into custody until the police obtain information from him. When the police let the alleged kidnapper go, Alex loses his cool and takes matters into his own hands. From this point on, we see how quickly the tables can turn and how the kidnapping of a child can fuel desperate and violent actions to the alleged kidnapper who becomes a prisoner at the hands of Keller Dover.

Keller Dover and Detective Loki's actions fuel much of the movie. Keller Dover is determined to find out the truth behind the kidnapping for himself, while Detective Loki follows a more rational and strategic approach to identifying the potential kidnapper. Detective Loki has his fair share of looking out for potential suspects and eventually finds Bob Taylor who is acting suspiciously at a candlelight vigil, and who runs away when seen. Although Bob Taylor is not critical to the plot, there could have been a better explanation of his story and the significance of the snakes and mazes to him than what we are given. Much of what is revealed about his life is determined posthumously, and we are left without the immediate and possibly intense story of the character to provide us with more background about what could be happening with the two little girls.

Keller Dover continues to torture Alex Jones, not realizing that he has the wrong victim and is torturing Alex without reason. There are many clues that are pieced together to reveal the actual kidnapper and when these come together, the story becomes more interesting.

Still, there is some information missing from the plot that I am curious about, and the movie did not succeed in filling in these gaps. What is the significance of the mazes? Do the mazes refer to a physical or psychological concept? There are a number of other plot gaps that could be better explained by the movie.
Hard to watch at times but well worth it for the excellent performances from both leads.

Rating: 9/10

I think Richard Roeper nailed it with his review of this excellent suspense/thriller.  This film is so good that it approaches the heights of similar crime masterpieces as Silence of the Lambs and Zodiac (one of my 10 favorite films).  It only falls short because its length is a bit too long.  Now, typically I'm last person to complain about a film's length because my mindset has always been that there's no such thing as "too much of a good thing" when it comes to movies.  Zodiac, for instance, happens to be a longer film than Prisoners by about 9 minutes, assuming you're watching the Director's Cut (it's only 5 minutes longer than the theatrical version and I've never watched that).  However, the difference between the films is that Zodiac keeps the facts, plot, and intrigue going at full force throughout the entire length of the picture, while Prisoners has a few moments that are arguably inconsequential to the story.  That isn't to say it has bad moments, because it does not, but given the film's pacing and slow-developing plot threads it could have benefitted from tighter editing, whereas the lengthier Zodiac uses all of its time very wisely.  However, this is a very minor issue and hardly any kind of deterrent.  If you haven't seen Prisoners, it is very well worth the time.  It is thoughtful, disturbing, chilling, and has many outstanding performances by every actor/actress.
Great directing and a pointless screenplay come together. In the end the three and a half stars is purely for Denis Villeneuve's ability.

Prisoners is beautifully shot and incredibly well acted, but it wastes a premise which should allow for deep characterizations on a more plot-driven paint-by-numbers mystery. A less twisty version that used the less-explosive parents played by Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, and Viola Davis as an emotional reference point rather than Gyllenhaal's detective character could be a true masterpiece. As it stands, Prisoners is just a moderately satisfying yarn.

This movie was dark and disturbing as hell, but it delivered edge of your seat tension on a regular basis. It tugs at your heart strings as a parent as having a child abducted is a parents worst nightmare. What lengths Jackman goes to is shocking, but it is something we all say we would do if needed. The end is great with some twists along the way.

This film certainly stands head and shoulders above many in its genre. Cinematography is incredibly impressive. The plot is masterfully composed and layered to suck you in and keep you on your toes. Aside from Jackman's overbearing performance, the acting is superb. Absolutely one of my favorite films from 2013.
Good cast and well made, but ultimately just too dark of a story/subject matter to be a completely satisfying experience.
A very well executed thriller with terrific performances .
awesome movie. A must watch for everyone.

A movie , where Jackman has given a good performance coming out of the superhero type "Wolverine". Gyllenhaal also does a very good job job as an emotional cop. The tortures are immensely emotional. One of the best thrillers of 2013.

Pure suspence in the most realistic way possible. One of the best movies of the year.
Subtracted half a star only because I saw through the twist since the very beginning. And Terrance Howard's character is a pussy. Good movie though.

Prisoners is a well developed story that stays with you hours after watching. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal both give a tour de France performances in this movie. While the movie and the story will give you the chills.

The story is a bout a father ( Hugh Jackman) who fights his way through breaking the law to find his kidnapped daughter as he fears that he is running out of time as the police is struggling to move forward with the case. 

Jack Gyllenhaal steals the scene as he plays Detective Loki who has never failed to solve a case. And Hugh Jackman comes strong  with his most emotional character who fights his inner demons before losing his ways. and this may be his most emotional performance so far. The rest of the cast does a very good job being secondary characters, and well devloped. Paul Dano is outstanding here as always  and as his career slowly takes to a better place.

The movie is smart and very entertaining. The character are real and the story is well told by the actors. The director delivers a beautiful weel shot film.

Great movie, good atmosphere, great story, a little slow but overall very good.

Exquisite rendition of a complex and dreadful reality. The way Hugh Jackman reacts, the volcano of emotions he shows throughout the plot, his impulsive violence lead to one of his greatest roles ever. Jake Gyllenhall is, again, bloody great, with his calm, Type B laid back attitude to solve the mystery, decomposing every scene and searching through the overwhelming horror that awaits. Howard delivers an impressive over-emotional and powerless role, drawn to desperation and sorrow more than courage and hope to find his daughter.

Prisoners chooses to focus on the families perspectives, and in particular, from a father facing a parents worse nightmare. Having a dark topic, the movie doesn't hold back from being disturbing, but it is careful and accurate in how it chooses to make an impact and express the story, making it an intriguing watch instead of a long, stressful ordeal.

"Making children disappear is the war we wage with God. Makes people lose their faith, turns them into demons like you". 
Muy buena la pelicula.

Prisoners is a dark, thrilling and disturbing film that raises many thought provoking questions on how far someone would go to protect a loved one. Both phenomenal performances from Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal

The intensity of the story and the thought that this does happens chills you to the bone. With intense turns from both Gyllenhaal and Jackman, prisoners is not for the faint of heart with intense torture scenes and hard facts about child abduction.

This is a very well made and great looking film.The acting is superb from all the cast the story is a bit generic.One of the biggest problems I had with this movie that it seems implausible some of the time and sometimes ridiculous.As a movie it's a very good one filled with terrific performances, and a well written script. This movie isn't a perfect movie but it isn't a bad movie either.

Truly excellent movie - great story/outstanding performances.  Disturbing to watch at at times but gripping from start to finish and raises many challenging moral dilemmas for the viewer. Highly recommended.
