An incredibly ambitious movie that is only, slightly, undone by its sprawling length and fairly predictable "twist" in the third act of the story.  This film isn't afraid to ask some really tough and disturbing questions, but it also has the strength to face them head on and not shy away from anything because it might be considered a sensitive subject.  The film is definitely morally complex and there's no one simple answer to the questions the film makes the audience ask.  I think that's the film's biggest positive, the fact that it doesn't shy away from the disturbing aspects of its story.  If I was put into this same situation that Keller found himself in, I don't think I'd have the heart to do what he did, even if I was a parent.  Because there's still that doubt, which Keller never had, that maybe Alex wasn't involved in the things he was accused of.  I'm gonna try my best not to spoil the film, but if I do I'll put a warning beforehand.  The things that Keller did, in his own mind, were justified because of the fact that he was doing his absolute best to get his daughter back.  Almost killing another human being, that may not have been involved, be damned.  That's the debate that the film is trying to bring up, would someone, in this same situation, have the guts to torture another human being for information he may not even be privy to.  As someone that doesn't have children, it'd be easy for me to say no at this moment in my life.  But the fact of the matter is that, at this moment, I can't see myself putting another human being through torturous hell.  Who am I to do that?  I've no right, especially when there's that doubt in your mind that maybe this person is innocent.  If I had 100% proof that this person did it, without a shadow of a doubt, I wouldn't have a problem with it.  But even if you're 99.9% sure, there's still that tiny chance that this person is innocent.  The fact that you'd have to live with that for the rest of your life.  That's gonna haunt you forever.  And even more so when what Keller did was done to someone that was a victim himself, he was a victim of the same people that kidnapped his daughter.  And this will be SPOILER-HEAVY...so skip ahead until I say.  Alex was already traumatized by the experience of being kidnapped at such a young age and being raised by the people that took him, to the point that Alex was no more than 10 years old when it came to mental age.  On top of that you have Keller beating him until his face is barely recognizable and being held hostage in the shower, where Keller would occasionally turn the shower on, from the outside, and have scalding hot water come out and burn the poor kid.  Alex will never be the same again.  By the end of the film, he's returned to his family but it's only obvious that he will never have a normal life again.  It's obvious that his family will have to suffer from the effects of the kidnapping and the abuse Keller put him through.  Keller's actions created waves that will ripple throughout the rest of Alex's life.  I don't think that's something the film really focuses on that much.  Yea, they do bring up that Keller, if found, would go to jail for what he did, but the consequences of his actions aren't fully explored.  The other interesting thing the film brings up is the fact that, whether you agree with his methods or not, Keller's actions, regardless of Alex's innocence or not, did, in fact, lead him to saving his daughter.  He doesn't save her directly, but if he hadn't tortured Alex, Loki wouldn't have found him and he wouldn't have been told by his boss to tell Alex's aunt of what happened to him, then he wouldn't have seen Alex's aunt drugging Anna, Keller's daughter, and he wouldn't have saved her.  Again, Keller indirectly saved his own daughter.  He wouldn't have been able to do this had he not tortured poor Alex.  So it raises some interesting moral conundrums.  There's no easy answer to the questions the film raises, but the film is smart enough to let you make up your own mind rather than shoving an agenda down your throat.  That's about it with the SPOILERS.  Like I said at the beginning, I did have a problem with the third act and how it became too much like a stereotypical suspense/thriller and its too long at times.  But the film benefits from a great cast, an incredible cast with one of Hugh Jackman's best performances, if not his best, and some beautiful cinematography.  So I think that makes the film easier to watch.  I don't think the film should've been cut down by much but 130 minutes would've been a perfect running length for this movie.  Regardless of that, this is still an incredible film that's definitely a very disturbing watch and it's definitely a film that's gonna haunt you long after you're done with it.

A sort of interesting look at the nature of man when we are pushed to our absolute limits and desperation. Paul Dano will probably be typecast forever as "creepy freak".

Let me start by simply saying this: if you have small children, do me a favor and do not watch this movie! As a man with no children even I was harshly affected by things that are depicted in this movie, to the point where it almost kept me up at night. Child abduction is a sad reality in our world, and I have little doubt that most parents would say they would do anything to get their kids back in that situation. What Prisoners accomplishes is putting that belief to the test...how far are you really willing to go? It seriously makes you think, and at some point you become introspective and start to wonder where you draw the line between right and wrong. That's a remarkable reaction to have when all you're doing is watching a movie. This movie is dark, bleak, and even when something positive happens you find yourself conflicted. There is no clear protagonist or antagonist for most of the film, because it shies away from black & white and takes place almost entirely in the grey. Ordinarily I'd hate that kind of ambiguity, but here it works. 

If you thought Hugh Jackman was intimidating as Wolverine you haven't seen anything yet. His portrayal of Keller is convincingly ruthless. I really believed that he was someone desperately trying to hang onto his sanity, as he fears letting his whole family down by losing his own daughter. Jake Gyllenhaal probably has the easiest role to play, because he seems to be the most level-headed of the characters. Naturally, being a police officer working the case, he has the benefit of not having as strong an emotional investment in the abductions. Yet you see him boil over occasionally as he is clearly impacted by the time spent with grieving families. I was impressed with Paul Dano's performance as a potential suspect. While he didn't have to say much, he did a great job of giving curious looks that kept you wondering whether he was hiding more than it appeared. But, for me, the best performances in Prisoners came from Terrence Howard and Viola Davis. As the parents of the other abductee they gave the viewers a relatable presence and helped ask the questions that you as a viewer were asking as well. Sadly they all but disappear in the second half of the film, which is my primary complaint.

In the first half of the movie I was so impressed with what they were doing. Although it was very violent, it wasn't gore just for the sake of gore like the Saw films. Instead it was driving the viewer to dark places and led me to question where I would morally draw the line. Do you at some point become the very evil that you seek to eliminate? That's where Terrence Howard and Viola Davis came in so handy, because they vocalized what I was feeling. This was so harsh that it was almost painful watching, but I couldn't look away because it was so well done. Yet somewhere about halfway through the film the entire story shifted gears. Suddenly it was running away from that moral debate, and into a by-the-books murder mystery. Now it is a high quality murder mystery, not a reject episode of CSI or something. It's just kind of disappointing that they changed focus so much. Even if they really wanted to switch themes it would have been nice if they gave a proper resolution to the dark road the first half led us down. No matter what Prisoners was a quality film that impacted me quite a bit. It was hard to watch, and I'm not going to seek it out again, but I'm glad I saw it.

The story focuses on two fathers named Keller Dover and Franklin Birch played by Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard who are having a Thanksgiving dinner along with their family until both their daughters go missing. They find a car parked outside with Alex Jones inside played by Paul Dano. He attempts to run away but gets arrested. Leading the investigation is Detective David Loki played by Jake Gyllenhaal who after arresting the driver is on the search but knowing that Keller's daughter Anna's life is at stake, he himself takes matters into his own hands as a maniac is waging a war against god by killing numerous children. The movie itself basically asks you about how far would you go to protect your children. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal were an unusual duo for the movie but they fit together very well. I haven't seen Jake in a movie for a long time which is why I wanted to watch this film badly and he was as good as always. Prisoners  gets a solid 8.5/10.

'Prisoners' is a gripping and intelligent crime thriller, that does well to portray the greatly undesirable nature of a missing person. Set in an eery American woodland town, a combination of possible suspects are gradually introduced to us, of whom the audience is able to try and solve the case themselves. Whilst when ultimately revealed you will find yourself saying "of course it was", I personally did not pinpoint the correct person. It was also interesting how the fathers attempt to take matters into their own hands, but ultimately make things worse for themselves; whilst interestingly justifying the title of the film. The two leads portray their characters well; particularly Gyllenhaal.

Despite its considerable length, the film itself did not seem to drag, instead remaining intense and interesting. Whilst each of the components to the case were infact intelligent, the ending left me somewhat disappointed. Many questions were left unanswered, with character links hard to define. A reliance on weak psychological reasoning  for the crime was also unsatisfactory. Of course this may have all been intended, but the links that were provided did seem somewhat desperate, making me want to give the director of the film a call to answer a couple of queries. Despite this, I thoroughly enjoyed this crime thriller, just falling short of 4 stars due to the question provoking ending.

The only complaints I have with this movie is the casting choice for Detective Loki & the lack of screen time for Terrance Howard's character. All else was great with special mention to Hugh Jackman for an emotional performance.

Review:
I found this movie to be extremely deep and full of intense drama throughout. I did have to watch it in 2 parts the length of the film, at 2 and a half hours, was quite much to keep up with, in that mood. There's loads of twists and turns throughout the movie which keeps it interesting, and the acting from all of the cast was great. The director should have shown some more of the other family that is also going through hell and the ending was left up to the audience to put together, which was a bit weird after getting drawn into the families trauma. The storyline is very well put together and it really does make the audience feel that they are going through the situation with the characters. In all its a great watch but it's quite long. Watchable!

Round-Up:
Hugh Jackman really does show a different side to his usual acting style. If it wasn't for his in depth performance, this movie wouldn't have been half as good. All of the other characters also bring reality to the film which makes the intensity throughout the movie a great watch. Although the film is quite long, I don't think that I would take anything out of the movie. It does flow well and the director really did cover every aspect of a bad situation that every is going through. I don't think that I would have gone with that type of ending, but in all, it's entertaining and enjoyable.

To entertain and tell a story. If I was in Hugh Jackman's shoes, in the situation of my child being abducted from me. i would do whatever it takes to get my child back.

I swear indie filmmakers often pen half of what would be a complete story. End it on a cliffhanger, with the idea that the viewer will decide what the overall message was. 

I don't like that. 

This film was brilliant, and could have had a clear ending, one that would have tied the loose ends and been a complete story. Instead I feel the same way I do when a great tv episode ends with "to be continued". Except there is no continuation, no finality. I feel that kind of story writing is half assed, in the name of being "artsy". Nevertheless "Prisoners" is definitely worth seeing.

Prisoners is a Mystery/Thriller film starring Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Terrence Howard, and Paul Dano. Prisoners is a film about two families who both of their daughters get kidnapped and both of the families with the help of the police, investigate and look for their daughters. This is a very dark, grim, and at times is a hard film to sit through. That being said, I have created a PainOmeter scale out of five (five being the worst) to inform you guys if you simply cannot take very violent and painful scenes. This will be addressed along will the film's final score. I loved this film! Hugh Jackman plays Anna's father and is the protagonist of the film. You can see how Jackman really loses his rag and does a great job as Keller Dover. There is one scene that involves Jackman doing something that I won't spoil but you will notice it and go WOW! The story is also very thought provoking and will keep you on the edge of your seat because of the direction and character building involved with this movie. Also Paul Dano who plays Alex Jones, is this weird adult with the IQ of a ten year old and is the main suspect of the investigation. I thought he nailed just the right tone of the character and was hard to "look at" at times. My favorite part of the film was surprisingly Jake Gyllenhaal's performance as the detective looking for the missing girls. Gyllenhaal still plays the role of a cop very well after all of that training for End Of Watch. Another great part of the film is that it manages to never take a rest on character building and story development. I hate when films give you time to take a break then start all over again and this film really avoids that entirely. I really have no problems with the film except for the runtime. Even though this was a great movie I just couldn't go for a perfect  5.   4 Stars 1-30-14

My Grade:  A- (93%),...PRISONERS, from Oscar (R)-nominated director Denis Villeneuve, stars Oscar (R) nominees Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal in a story that poses the question: How far would you go to protect your child? Keller Dover (Jackman) is facing every parent's worst nightmare. His six-year-old daughter, Anna, is missing, together with her young friend, Joy, and as minutes turn to hours, panic sets in. The only lead is a dilapidated RV that had earlier been parked on their street. Heading the investigation, Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) arrests its driver, Alex Jones (Paul Dano), but a lack of evidence forces the only suspect's release. Knowing his child's life is at stake, the frantic Dover decides he has no choice but to take matters into his own hands. But just how far will this desperate father go to protect his family?

Okay, I'll admit it, I was wrong about this movie.  Okay, not entirely.  I was right that it would be far too broody and dank, but I was wrong about how the plot would unfold.  I won't go into specifics, but the bad guy wasn't who I was expecting.  That said, it's a little muddled and overlong, but plays out pretty well.  Hugh Jackman (The Wolverine) gives a convincing performance - one that rightly put him in early Oscar buzz, before the art house flicks took over.  It's one of those movies that's chock full of capable actors, but some shine more than others.  I still don't see the appeal of Jake Gyllenhaal (End of Watch), but he's apt in this flick. Viola Davis (Beautiful Creatures) and Mario Bello (Grown Ups 2) shine, Terrance Howard (Lee Daniel's The Butler) turns in his best performance in some time, Paul Dano (Looper) is predictably apt yet strange, and Melissa Leo (Olympus Has Fallen) continues to impress.  Honestly, next to Jackman, she's the standout of the picture.  It's pretty dark, but it's also well-acted, well-paced, and fulfilling enough that it doesn't fit the typical Oscar mold.

This is probably the bleakest film of 2013 and does it perfectly. The film focuses on two families who get together during Thanksgiving in rural Pennsylvania. After the daughters of both families vanish, things take a darker turn when there is belief that they were probably abducted. Hugh Jackman gives a chilling and dark turn as Keller Dover, a religious man who is brought to his breaking point after he feels that the police haven't done their job properly, while Jake Gyllenhaal gives a terrific supporting performance as Detective Loki, who stops at nothing to find the children and their kidnapper. The supporting actors are also terrific, such as Terence Howard as a grieving father and Viola Davis as his grieving wife, Maria Bello as Jackman's drunken wife, Paul Dano as the supposed timid kidnapper and Melissa Leo as Dano's aunt. Roger Deakins' cinematography is bleak and wonderfully supports the film's plot, while Denis Villeneuve's direction is flawless and the script by Aaron Guzikowski is haunting. Throughout the entire film you side with Jackman, while the film takes several terrific twists leading up to a surprising ending. Bravo.

Acting was solid and you could genuinely feel the emotions spewed by Hugh Jackman. If you liked films like "Se7en" and "Zodiac", you sure as hell will appreciate this brother.

Very good. Hugh Jackman would have deserved an Oscar nomination for his believable role as a desperate father trying to do everything he can. The whole cast is really solid but maybe Loki's character is a bit faceless, since he mainly has to move the story forward. Prisoners is nicely shot, thanks to Mr. Deakins. Especially the night scenes and rainy highways look stunning. The film also has atmospheric sound design. The rhythm of the movie is delightfully calm and peaceful, and I think that makes the characters and the story feel real. In my opinion there are just a couple of scenes that may be a bit unnecessary. Nothing substantial though. Prisoners is one of the best thriller dramas out there!

one of the best movies I've seen in a long time.  So real life and believable from where I come from.  This movies setting looks just like my home town.  the actors are great and the suspense is awesome.  You feel like you're with Hugh Jackman in trying to do what you can to find his daughter. A most bleak & disturbing movie featuring an outstanding (all-talented, all-star) cast induced into a morose state.  PRISONERS is relentless in its gloominess.  There's nothing pleasant in this grim kidnapping-revenge story.  On the plus side, there is, for one,  that cast of solid performers, each giving it their 100%, and the dour artistic vision of Quebec Director Denis Villeneuve (of INCENDIES, POLYTECHNIQUE and MAELSTROM fame) and his total control on the film's uneasy mood.  PRISONERS hits all the right buttons to create two and a half hours of tension, fear and anxiety.  While it's very good, there's nothing nice about it.

Initially, I thought this was going to be the typical kidnapping or Taken type remake. I was pleasantly surprised that it was not. This is a movie that as soon as you think you know what is going to happen, the plot twists and turns and you are back to square one; and this happens multiple times during the movie. For this reason the movie went buy rather quickly even though it is certainly longer than the average. I thought the acting was done very well. Hugh Jackman does a better job than I thought playing the father figure, but he really shines when he has to play the tough guy father figure. Jake Gyllenhaal does an equally good job portraying a detective that is put in a difficult situation that creates a tension between the law and moral obligations. I realize that this is R-rated, but I feel it is important to note this movie does have some rather violent and disturbing material. I was even surprised by some of it. So, for those that are squeamish to these sorts of things you may want to look elsewhere. That being said, this is one of the best movies I have watched in a very long time.

Keller Dover will stop at nothing, including taking the law into his own hands, to find his daughter.

"He killed sixteen children.  He said he'd kill more."

Denis Villeneuve, director Polytechnique, Incendies, and Enemy, delivers Prisoners.  The storyline for this picture is very compelling and contains a wide arrange of eccentric characters.  The dialogue is solid and the action scenes are tense.  The cast delivers remarkable performances and include Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Paul Dano, and Terrence Howard.

"I'm going to go help the police."

I went into this not knowing anything about it except the title and the two lead actors.  And I typically have a hard time with Hugh Jackman. But what an amazing movie! It's one of the best and my favorites from 2013.  It's not a movie that you can easily forget.  How is this not a best picture nominee? It's better than most of the nominated movies. Just when you think you have the movie figured out, it twists on you. Very suspenseful.  The story was scary and agonizing (in a good way) but so fascinating. (By agonizing in a good way, I mean that it wasn't so painfully realistic that you couldn't enjoy it. I'm looking at you Pursuit of Happiness.) The cinematography was just wonderful. When I saw it was Roger Deakins, I understood why. What great story telling. And acting. and directing. Just...WOW! Also, it doesn't hurt that Jake Gyllenhaal was very hot in this role. just saying. Also, Melissa Leo is one of the best actors ever! What a chameleon! She's like the female Gary Oldman. I could gush about this movie all day. It was so wonderful! It's a darn shame it's not getting any recognition.

It has a vast sense of dread that begins as merely a worry, but unfolds into a panic, then to a damp, dark pit of despair in which there isn't one ray of light to be found.

Hugh jackman is absolutely fantastic in the role as a father pushed to the edge as he tries to get his daughters back. Jake Gyllenhaal is also fantastic as the cop on the case. Riveting, thought-provoking; one of the best police procedurals I've ever seen.  Goes far, far beyond the usual tropes of the genre. Great acting by everyone involved, working off a razor-sharp script that's full of twists and tension.  Must-see viewing for anyone who loves a good crime story.

A psychological thriller of two girls who are kidnapped and the lengths the families will go to find them.

Even before I saw the suspenseful and mysterious drama Prisoners, I thought the movie was extremely undersold for a film starring two Oscar-nominated actors as great as Hugh Jackman & Jake Gyllenhaal and directed by Oscar-nominee Denis Villeneuve.  After seeing it, it's definitely surprising how it has stayed under the radar this long.  Villeneuve has created a dark and edgy feel that keeps you uneasy while pulling at your heart to ache for the friends and family of missing persons in general.  Somehow the story struck me as horrific and unbelievable while still lying in the realm of possibility.  
	Hugh Jackman plays a role I've never seen him attempt and one I think might be different than any he's every played before.  As the father of a six-year-old girl who goes missing with her young friend, Keller Dover (Jackman) makes a very convincing frantic parent.  Having to act out every mother and father's worst nightmare can't be an easy task and Jackman left me impressed, as always.  
	  Detective Loki (Gyllenhaal) quickly locates an old RV that had been spotted down the street prior to the girls disappearance and arrests its driver, Alex Jones (Paul Dano).  Although he is the lone suspect and plenty suspicious, a lack of evidence requires them to release him.  Desperate and knowing he's running out of time, Dover loses faith in Detective Loki and has no choice but to take the situation into his own hands.  
	Overall, I felt the acting was impeccable.  Terrence Howard joins Jackman and Gyllenhaal as the father of the second missing girl and sheds different light on how one might react when faced with the same horrendous situation.  I was fairly engaged throughout the entire 155 minute movie.  Usually, I don't see a need for films like this to be quite as long, but in this case Villeneuve did an outstanding job of holding my attention and intrigue.  If there is one thing I could say about this movie that bothered me, it might be the ending.  Although it didn't ruin the film in any way, it did feel like a bit of a cop-out.  Without giving away too much, it definitely has a bit of a cliff-hanger ending.  
This film is not for the overly sensitive, weak stomached, or faint-of-heart.  It is the type of movie that leaves you truly contemplating how far you would go to save those that are most important to you.

Well made and very well acted. The problem is this is a film that takes itself very seriously indeed and then requires it's characters to behave in totally unbelievable ways. The end result is in a way impressive but very jarring.

Prisoners is a story we have all seen before. But, this story is still capturing with high suspense and high questions of morality. Jake Gyllenhaal gives an especially great performance and leads the viewer to not know who to cheer for. An intense drama and thriller sure to keep you on the edge of your seat.
You'll never forget this movie. it's great and horrifying.

Prisoners is one of the top five best if not the single greatest movie of 2013! And when considering that the academy of motion picture arts only nominated it for best cinematography, it is also one of the most underrated! Prisoners deserved at least half of the available nominations, including Hugh Jackman for Best Actor (his best performance yet I think), Jake Gyllenhaal and Terrance Howard for Best Supporting Actors, Melissa Leo and Viola Davis for Best Supporting Actresses, Denis Villeneuve for Best Director, Aaron Guzikowski for Best Original Screenplay, and of course, Best Cinematography for Roger Deakins. But the real star hear, besides Hugh Jackman of course, is Paul Dano. Paul delivered the most powerful performance in a movie filled with equally powerful actors and their own performances. I thought that if Prisoners was to be nominated for anything it would be for Paul Dano's disturbing portrayal as the mentally challenged suspect. 

The more I sit and think about the nominating process for the Oscars, the more I come to realize that they are all a bunch of hypocritical old schoolers who relish in snubbing actors and directors and giving them to people who are far less deserving, I.e. Shakespeare in Love over Saving Private Ryan? Chicago over Gangs of New York? Forest Gump over Pulp Fiction? What Were They Thinking! That last one is a little unfair because Tom Hanks deserved that Oscar, but Pulp Fiction was clearly the better film. 

If you have an ounce of respect for the art of cinema, or if you just love movies in general, you will do yourself a favor and see this movie. It is living proof that the academy of motion picture arts and sciences is one big joke! Another one to look at is Captain Phillips. Another great performance from another great actor, Tom Hanks, that was snubbed big time!

A mature mystery that pays just as much attention to its characters and subtext--how fear buried deep down, when hit just right, can turn a good man into a monster; how our sense of justice can often cripple our logic and compassion; how doing evil to fight evil is a pointless and destructive act that just feeds back into itself.

The film's unofficial tagline of "Hope for the best, prepare for the worst" sums it up very well. It's dark and disturbing, probably nightmarish for parents. Not anything particularly unique or extraordinary, but it's a more than capable thriller with some great surprises and strong performances.

Movies like "Silence of the Lambs" and "Mystic River" are pretty much set the standard in the crime thriller genre and while "Prisoners" doesn't seem to bring that iconic feeling it does bring that subversive element as you feel more involved in the story as the complicated plot progresses.
    Jake Gyllenhaal carries the role of the law enforcing detective with such a bizarre attitude he becomes just as hard to predict as the criminal himself. While all actors do great in bringing the sentiment of anxiety and lack of safety to the viewer  the real surprise is the performance of Hugh Jackman. Probably one of the most likeable characters in modern cinema Jackman manages to come across as a torn human being, forced to do unspeakable acts of violence in order to save the ones he loves. 
  The movie simply absorbs you in its cold, complicated story, even though it can get a bit too loaded and too complicated to follow.  At the end of the mystery, when everything seems to be unwrapped and solved the last frames leave a continuous shiver down your spine and makes you feel genuine fear, and that is not a bad thing.

Director: Denis Villeneuve.

Writer: Aaron Guzikowski.

Staring: Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Viola Davis, Terrence Howard, Maria Bello, Melissa Leo and David Dastmalchian.

Running Time: 153 minutes.

Rating: R for Disturbing Violent Content including Torture, and Language throughout.

Let's get this right out of the way for Prisoners: It is not a happy a movie. If you're expecting a good time or to come out with a smile on your face, this is not your type of movie. You would be much better off popping in something like Pacific Rim or seeing if Frozen is still playing where you live. But even if a film is horribly depressing, that doesn't mean you shouldn't watch it if given the chance. Far from it with something like Prisoners, the English language debut of Canadian director Denis Villeneuve (Incendies). While its grueling content and odd plot points may cause some contention with viewers, Prisoners delivers on damn near every cylinder you should expect to see in a good mystery: Excellent performances, a plot that keeps you guessing till the very end, haunting cinematography and some interesting debates on morality and what one would do and how far they would go to save a loved one.

One day, somewhere in Pennsylvania, a small get together with two families is going on. Set sometime around Thanksgiving, the two families The Dovers (Hugh Jackman playing Keller and Maria Bello playing Grace) and The Birches (Viola Davis playing Nacy and Terrence Howard playing Franklin) are having a nice get together. Everybody's laughing, chowing down tasty food, just having a good time together. The teens hang out while the youngsters, Anna Dover and Joy Birch, are off playing around in the neighborhood. 

A few hours latter, the two youngest disappear. An investigation is soon kicked into motion and headed by Detective Loki (Jake Gyllenhaal) to find out who it is Eventually, the find a suspect in the form of mentally handicapped Alex Jones (Paul Dano). But due to the fact there is a lack of evidence on whether he did it or not, he winds up being released. The father of one of the families, Keller Dover, however, becomes increasingly unstable over the course of the investigation, resorting to his own (brutal) methods to find out if Alex actually did it or not.

So yes, as one can tell from that synopsis up top, Prisoners isn't what one would call a "feel good movie". On top of that, it isn't one that goes by quick. It fully expects you to sit down and watch as it takes you on a long journey of what its like to have a child taken from you. Whether you have or haven't had kids, you feel steeped in the misery and horror of what the parents go through in the film. Hell, the film was originally slapped with an NC-17 rating before it got re-edited with a R. Frankly, after watching the film itself, it doesn't surprise me that it almost got the former.

Another interesting note to make is that in addition to being a Drama-Mystery-Thriller, the film is also a play on morality. Most of the characters never stay clean for long, especially High Jackman's character, who pulls some especially dickish things to find his kid. As seen in the trailers (don't worry; this all happens in the first half hour), he winds up kidnapping Alex to find out where the children are, but what he does will make your stomach churn. Even as the film went as on, I found myself conflicted with his character, wanting him to find his kids but I wished he'd stop being such an ass in trying to find his kid. The film itself and its characters are even asking themselves if what they're doing is justified or not.

What I found interesting about the film is that you never really know who's who or what till the end. For the majority of the film's running time, it keeps you guessing on whether Alex did it or not. Is he playing stupid? Does he genuinely not know what happened to the kids? Was he manipulated into doing what he did? It's like being in a maze, a nightmarish labyrinth from where there is no escape from until the very end.

The film's performances are uniformly excellent, with Hugh Jackman showing us a scary side of his acting abilities that we haven't seen before. His character shows a broad range of anger, ruthlessness and regret. The performance as Dover is so good, it outright makes his iconic Wolverine role look downright pathetic by comparison. I can also safely say that thanks to this role, Jackman's was able to partially redeem himself after being in last year's blunderpiece Movie 43. He's not quite there yet, but I hold him in much higher regard than I did after 43. The rest of the supporting cast also give great performances as well. Jake Gyllenhaal continues to be one of the best actors working today, with an almost equally compelling side role as the determined Detective Loki. One scene in particular that stands out for me with him is when flips out in his office. I won't say what happens in regards to that part in what triggers him, but damn, he really lost it in a big way.

Terrence Howard and Paul Dano bring their goods to the table as well, as does Maria Bello and Viola Davis. Melissa Leo also shows up as Alex Jones' mother, Holly, and while she doesn't have that many scenes in the film, she is compelling enough to keep an admirable presence on-screen. Even the kids who play Joy and Anna (Kyla Drew Simmons and Erin Gerasimovich, respectively) do their roles without some kind of saccharine or sickly-sweet kind of way that one would usually expect from kids in movies.

Shot by famous cinematographer Roger Deakins (Skyfall, No Country For Old Men, The Shawshank Redemption), Prisoners looks unsurprisingly beautiful in its imagery. Damn near every frame looks downright perfect, with scenes that look like they were molded by a paint brush than a camera. Denis and Deakins obviously know what they're doing, and I hope that they collaborate more in the future. Then there's the score by Jóhann Jóhannsson, who achieves haunting yet minimalist work that help establish the mood of the picture quite excellently.

If there were any problems I had with the film, I'd say it would be some plot elements. There's something that happens to Paul Dano's character in which he ends up disappearing from the public eye and it doesn't really get addressed until the last 30 minutes of the movie. Arguably, due to the investigation of the girls, I can see how their disappearance could be held in higher regard than Dano's but it was still a little something that bothered me.

Then there's how the film handles its clues, foreshadowing and red-herrings, in which it maybe just a little too clever for its own good. It's great to see a film keep its audience guessing all the way through and then pull the rug under their feet when they least expect it, but it felt like the movie was getting a little overly complicated. Not that it was a major hindrance to the film's quality, but I can see how some would be fed up with the plot twists and the loopty loops the film pulls from time to time.

It's a shame that the film was missed at the Oscar season. It was a big contender in the first couple of weeks it came out but due to being swarmed by a mountain of other films (Gravity, 12 Years A Slave, The Wolf of Wall Street), it sadly got overlooked and wound up with only a nom for Best Cinematography. Yet, in spite of that, its more than worth checking out. Its imagery, performances and plot won't leave you for a while and it will keep you engaged all the way through its long running time.

Prisoners is one of the better reviewed films of 2013 that failed to be mentioned by a number of critic groups and/or various guilds throughout the Award Season of Hollywood after all was said-and-done.  The movie - from Oscar-nominated Québécois director Denis Villeneuve (Incendies [2010]) - earned critical praise upon its initial release in the fall of last year as did its large and respected ensemble cast.  Cast members Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal both had Oscar-talk circulating about them and the consensus on Jackman was that it was perhaps his best performance to date which was remarkable as the actor had just earned his first Oscar nomination the year prior for Les Misérables!  As I watched Prisoners, I found myself agreeing with much of the critical praise it had received and found it to be one of those rare acclaimed films that "the masses" (us!) and critics could both agree upon!  It is a gripping and engrossing, heavily dramatic psychological thriller about good guys and bad guys ... but mostly about those who inhabit the gray areas in between.  When two six-year-old girls of two married couples - Jackman/Maria Bello (The Cooler) and Viola Davis (Doubt)/Terrence Howard (Hustle & Flow) - go missing, all fingers point to the perversely pleased local simpleton Alex Jones(Paul Dano - 12 Years a Slave) whose cooperative aunt (Melissa Leo - Frozen River) believes him to be innocent although she knows he is a troubled soul.  When the local PD (Gyllenhaal) runs into dead-ends and Jones is released for lack of evidence, the desperate fathers do what desperate fathers will do to find their missing daughters.  Jackman becomes a self-righteous judge and jury via a frighteningly easy transformation but he still needs to find the girls.  The film asks tough and disturbing questions (with some ghastly images) an audience might not want to hear or consider and the film is a bit long (2.5 hours); but I believe it to be so morally confounding one cannot quit it.
The trailers for this movie don't do any justice for the film. Outstanding performances and intriguing characters make this movie a "Must See" for anybody!
Prisoners is not only a solid thriller, but a emotional and complex exploration of lengths of human obsession.

No Spoilers until marked.

This movie represents some of the best acting, and tightest plot spinning I have ever seen on screen! Prepare yourself for a very emotional, suspenseful, anxiety ridden maze-like trip through a parent's worst nightmare- this movie hits home hard for those of us with children but it's breathtaking raw emotion, keep-you-guessing type plot, and fantastic acting makes it well worth the heartache.

The acting is fantastic all around but Jake Gyllenhaal, Hugh Jackman, and Paul Dano steal the show! By the end of the movie, I was left especially hungry to learn more about Gyllenhaal's "Detective Loki." The details of his character are incredibly interesting and fitting for his role. Jackman was intense... and I do mean INTENSE. His visceral desperation and anger are felt more than just seen. And Dano brings something to the screen that I have never before seen. We are told he is a mentally disadvantaged man with an intellect no greater than a ten year old and the way this plays out on screen is just brilliant. I'll leave it at that for this non-spoiler part of the review. The rest of the cast does very well also, particularly Terrence Howard and Viola Davis as Franklin and Nancy Birch though the movie does not center around their characters quite as much.

The cinematography was brilliant. There were some scenes that could easily have been movie posters, I won't spoil them for you. Overall the movie was beautifully shot.

As far as music and sound go, I have to say I don't remember any of the music from the film. This is not necessarily a bad thing as I would prefer it not be memorable in a bad way so as to distract from what is being portrayed but it also means that it wasn't amazing. The sound, however, is a different story. There were moments of complete silence in the movie where the silence itself was a sound effect. There were intense moments that were accented by incredibly clear and poignant sound that fit the scene.

Plot, oh boy was there plot! A great, edge of the seat, thrilling plot that just smacked me in the face every couple of minutes! The movie goes on for about 2.5 hours and the whole time I was glued to the screen. What an incredible story!

********WARNING: HUGE SPOILERS BELOW, don't read any further unless you have seen the movie or for some reason just want to destroy the experience of watching this film for yourself.
*************************************************************************************************************************************
Ok, just so we are all on the same page, I am going to go through the plot and piece things together since there seems to be a bit of confusion on Who Bobby Taylor was, how joy escaped, and what the Leo's were actually doing to children.

We start off being introduced to Keller Dover and his son , Ralph. Keller recites the Lord's Prayer and his son lines up a shot for a deer. This scene is blatantly metaphorical for "doing what is necessary" in Keller's perspective. It also shows how Ralph is becoming a man. This plays well against Alex Jones because it shows you what Alex never had and why he isn't a "man" but rather still a 10 year old boy. (Obviously abuse and drugs/snake venom had something to do with it too). This is how Keller works, he doesn't enjoy killing the deer but it is necessary to him and the ends justify the means. The prayer shows us that he doesn't "shoot the deer" for his own enjoyment, it is a means by which he can get what he needs for his family. This foreshadows the exact sentiment felt when he tortures Alex.

We can now skip ahead to the children disappearing. We meet Detective Loki. He has tattoos but he hides them constantly. He clasps his hands to hide his knuckle tattoos and he buttons his shirt to the top button to hide his neck tattoos. He wears a masonic ring, His tattoos and his opening lines indicate that he has an interest in Zodiac signs and astrology- all information we are given throughout the film indicates that he had a rough past and was possibly a criminal turned cop. Loki is a prisoner of his past.

Keller becomes a prisoner to his desperation, doing things he would never have done under normal circumstances, likewise his wife becomes a prisoner to her medication as a way of dealing with the tragedy of losing her daughter. Ralph becomes a prisoner of the house, his father the jailor. He is told to watch over his mother and stay home. Alex becomes Keller's prisoner in a very literal sense. The children are obviously prisoners- I could go on. Everyone in the movie is a prisoner to something by this point.

The RV is gone over CSI-Miami style and nothing is found- this is because Alex merely let the kids in, let them play and sing while he drove them to his "aunt's" house. This is what he meant when he said "They didn't cry until I left them." It also explains Ms. Leo's later comment that he only played with the children. Loki continues tracking down leads by visiting local sex offenders and happens upon a body in the creepy as f*** basement/crawl-space/nightmare-dungeon under the Priest's house. This body is wearing a necklace with a circular maze etched on it, hmmmmm. It is also explained that the man has kidnapped and killed at least 16 children. This man is Ms. Leo's husband that she said disappeared after a fight. He is also the "invisible man" that the book in Bobby Taylor's house is about.

Speaking of Bobby Taylor, aka "The Snake Guy," he was a former abductee, taken by the Leo's when he was just a boy. He escaped somehow, it isn't ever explained, but he is now damaged and seeks to recreate the efforts of his captors to try and understand their motives. He is obsessed with it, going as far as stealing abducted children's clothes, spattering them with pigs blood and claiming to have killed them. He buries child-manikins in his yard after bashing in their heads. He is a mixture of a victim with Stockholm syndrome, a child, and a copycat killer. He too, is a prisoner to his past, he even goes so far as to wear the same jacket as Ms. Leo does (more on that later).

So the Leo's have had a process that is now continued only by Ms. Leo since Mr. Leo is dead. By the end of the movie, we should be able to conclude that The Leo's had a son who died of cancer. They were religious prior to this and afterward, unable to reconcile the tragedy with their religion, they reject their religion and begin to "wage war on god" by abducting other people's children, creating "demons" aka the broken, parents of the abducted children. They do this alone at first and later by having Alex find and pick up children. The children are then delivered to the Leo's house where they are given Kool-Aid laced with ketamine and LCD and told that they can leave when they have solved a book fool of mazes. The catch is, the last maze, the same one that Mr. Leo wore around his neck, is unsolvable. Eventually the children are injected with snake venom and buried. This is exactly what happened to Joy and Anna but Joy was able to get away before she was injected. (Some might argue that there is a different order to it but this is the gist. All these things happen, it may be done in a different order depending on the kid)

How did Joy get away? The movie tells you but it is a bit difficult to piece it together. We see Joy's flash backs when she is in the hospital room and it shows a person wearing a jacket carrying Anna in the right arm and reaching for Joy (who is running away) with her left. It also shows two bottles of the laced Kool-Aid, one full and one half empty. We can deduce that it was Ms. Leo in the Jacket, and that Joy did not drink her Kool-Aid. This fits with what Ms. Leo said about having to move the girls inside after Detective Loki was snooping around the car outside. Thus when Ms. Leo was moving them inside, Joy ran away and was picked up by a passing motorist.

All this is pieced together when Keller visits Joy in the hospital and she says "You were there. She put tape on our mouths!" Keller thinks back and realizes the only place he has gone where there was a female suspect was the Leo's home. Joy must have heard his voice through the thin walls. He gains entry by half-heartedly pretending to offer assistance fixing up the house and ignores the obviously hidden weapon in her hand. This is the only part of the plot that made me cringe. We all knew she had a gun, and Keller should have too.

So he gets drugged, shot, and thrown in the pit- Loki finds Alex in Keller's old apartment building, in pretty bad shape assumingly. He is tasked with telling Ms. Leo they found Alex. Detective Loki lets himself in, finds Ms. Leo injecting Anna with venom and a firefight ensues, in which Loki gets grazed on the head and Ms. Leo gets gunned down. The scene where Loki drives Anna to the hospital was amazing. The lighting, the blurry eyes, the rain, the anxiety... MAN! PERFECT!

The end of the movie wraps up pretty neatly. Loki hears Keller blowing the whistle and we know that he finds Keller, and we know that Keller goes to Jail (based on previous comments made by Loki in the hospital).

This movie used the maze as a theme constantly. Think about how you would solve a maze on a piece of paper, following one trail until it dead ends and having to backtrack and pick a different branch, sometimes overlooking the right path until it is the only one left. That is how the plot played out, that is how each prisoner felt inside their prison. Beautiful.

"Prisoners" is totally messed up.  This shocking story of abduction, devastation, and brutal torture contains several mysteries that all tie together in the end.  Its content seems like it belongs in a late-summer thriller but it works well in this Oscar-caliber drama.  The script is well written, introducing important facts at all of the right times, making you think that you have it all figured out, and then keeping you (and all of the characters) guessing until the very end.  I found an internal battle forming within myself as I didn't want Paul Dano to be guilty but hoped that he was simply so that I wouldn't feel bad about him enduring all of that torture.  Dano is an underrated actor with impressive roles in "Being Flynn," "Little Miss Sunshine," and "Ruby Sparks" on his resume.  It may seem like he does not do much acting as Alex Jones but playing a role that communicates through body language instead of spoken dialogue requires a refined skill.  Hugh Jackman is good but sometimes it just felt like we needed a break from his overwhelming amount of anger.  The supporting roles are the most impressive as Maria Bello creates some nice emotional moments when the depression overwhelms her and she becomes dependant on pills to keep her numb.  Plus Terrence Howard and Viola Davis bring another dynamic to the torture scenes as they take on the "good cop" roles.  The real feature in this film is Melissa Leo, nearly unrecognizable as Holly Jones who progressively reveals layers of her life throughout the film.  You'll never see the end coming although you'll want to see the end of the torture arrive much earlier than it does.  There is something twisted about "Prisons" but that might be what makes the film so dreadfully attractive.

Prisoners was not what I was expecting both in a good and not so good manner. It almost comes off as two films in one, even though the connective tissue to make it a single story is all there and is established throughout the film. But instead of connecting everything up in the end in a convincing fashion, elements are added haphazardly until the feel of the end of the film (crime thriller in the realm of Kiss The Girls) is far removed from the feel of the beginning (morality tale like In The Bedroom).

The film is enjoyable, the performances are quite strong, and overall the film is good. But the writing is simply not all there to make the transition from beginning to end work as well as it could have with just a little more evidence spread throughout to make it more of a crime thriller.

As an aside, I also felt that the tacked on bit of relief in the final scene was kind of a copout for audiences that can't take dark endings. But that could just be my preference for films that don't give people an easy out and are left to their own answers.

There was a period in American filmmaking history where every movie looked great. All the shots were crisp and clear, the lighting was superb and every movie ,wether it was an idnie film or big blockbuster epic, looked high def. This was inbetween 2007-2011 and it was called The Deakins Period.  Roger Deakins is probably the most famous and influential cinematographer of our generation. Every single one of his movies are superbly photographed. Ever since No Country for Old Men he has created the most amazing looking movies of all time. From The Reader to True Grit to Skyfall all the way to the tiny indies like Doubt, Revolutionary Road and A Serious Man. If you just look at the trailers for these films then you'll understand the breathtaking shots this man produces.  You could tell that after Deakins perfected the art of photography in No Country, every movie after that tried their best to look as good as a Deakins film. Some succeeded while others only touched the magic of this man's work. Soon enough every movie looked good enough to eat, but none of them could beat the beauty of a Deakins film. Every single shot of his is like a carefully crafted painting with strokes of lighting and camera movement perfection. Any director priviliged enough to work with him gets to have the best looking movie of that year. And that is exactly what Prisoners is. Yes, Prisoners of course looks amazing. All the shots were like big frames of candy for your brain to soak in. I could never take my eyes off the screen because of just how amazing every frame looked. It was so lush and clean. Hell, even a doorknob could reach the heights of the sexiest models on the planet. The dark shades and yellow hues made everything feel dark and gloomy, being exactly what the film is. Prisoners is no fun family going film ride. Actually i suggest if you have kids then dont go at all because you will never want your little babies to be even a 10 foot radius away from you after experiencing this frightfully realistic motion picture. 

  Prisoners is about child abduction. Yes, that's what Prisoners is about. One of the worst subjects in society's history has a whole 2 and a half hour movie about it. It stars Hugh Jackman, Jake Gylenhall, Terence Winter, Paul Dano and Viola Davis. Prisoners chronicles the abduction of two regular middle class suburban little girls and how both the families cope with the situation and deal with it in their own way while a dedicated detective tries to find the girls before anything gets out of hand (And yes, trust me, things get out of hand very quickly). Prisoners is (almost) perfectly made. The mood of the films is meek and dreary, giving out a dreadful sense of worry the entire way through. It has moments of incredible suspense especially during the opening before the girls are kidnapped, A foreshadowing eeriness crawls through the first ten minutes or so and you're just waiting in horrible anticipation for the dreaded kidnapping moment to occur. As a hardcore drama thriller, Prisoner's tone keeps that definition the entire way through. It never veers into action or dark comedy because this subject matter is nothing to take lightly. It's completely serious  but not in a way where it's not entertaining. Its suspence keeps you on the edge of your seat waiting for what will happen next. The film never misses a beat and although the film drags on a bit, it keeps you anticipating for what will happen next, making the 150 minute runining time more bearable. This is all thanks to director Denis Villenueve's incredible skill in precisee camera work and setting up the correct mood. 

  Hugh Jackman deserved an Oscar nomination for Best Lead Actor because he just kills it in this movie. He plays a tough, fighting father who will do anything , I mean ANYTHING to find his kid. Jackman just takes over the film with his commanding presence. Jackman's brutally tough persona along with his rough figure shows that he's scary person in general even if he is a loving father. Jackman has quite a few emotional scenes throughout and he pulls off every single one of them with perfection and deep emotion. What makes Jackman's chracter so great is that we hate the things he does to people so he can find his kids, but we understand where he's coming from and sympathize with him even during his most immoral scenes. Thus making us question our own moral values and what we'd do in sitaution like this. Would we follow Jackman's harsh torterous  ways or would we follow Terrence Winter's character and do what's "right"instead of risking everything to find our kids. Terence Winter's performance  EXCEPTIONAL. He doesn't have a big role i n this film and that bothers me. We get ALOT of Jackman's POV during the entire film but we hardly get to see what Winter's chracter is thinking or what he does. We dont get his side of the story and what he experiences. There isn't an even ground between the two characters thus making a very one sided story. The rest of the film is about Detective Loki (hell yeah, LOKI) played by Jake Gylenhall. Detective Loki is the one that is actually doing the investigating into the two missing girls. He's very dedicated to his job making him determined to find these two girls. His character is extremely realistic in a sense that he's not finding all the answers very quickly. He finds clues and leads but most of them don't mean anything forcing him to start all over again. He becomes frustrated  and lost to where he almost starts a whole new investigation on a totally different suspect. But this also creates flaws in the story. Even I, as a viewer, knew who the kidnapper was and i fit the clues faster together than the characters in the story. That took me out of the film when i figured out that i was smarter than the detective himself which reminded me that this is a character not a real person that i should be invested in. Also, the film drags on in bits where it seems like they're just killing time so there can be more suspence. Yes, it builds itself up to an awesome climax but it seemed like it was deliberatley doing it and trying to force me to be in a suspenceful mood. If screenwriter Aaron Guzikowski  had just written a more faster paced film with substantially better character development and a less predictable story, then Prisoners might have been a perfect film. This is not an easywatch for anyone. There's torture, suicide and just a a bad mood oeverall. But these things add to the movie making it s bit more sharp and entertaining. Prisoners represents the immorality inside all of us. No one in the world is a perfectly good person, becuase the devil lurks in us all. Great acting, sharp direction and a amazing cinematography, Prisoners is a substantially great film. 

Recomendation: Not an easy watch for anyone, Prisoners is a must see for people  with a tough heart but not necesarilly an intellegent mind.

I am not going to write too many sentences on "Prisoners", so therefore I will set you free with not too many "punalties" on my behalf. However, I do have to commend Director Denis Villenueve's brilliant thriller about a desperate father's actions after his daughter is missing. Hugh Jackman delivers the best performance of his career as the Pennsylvania working-class father Keller Dover. On a Thanksgiving, Dover and his wife and two kids were celebrating the holiday at their best friends' home who are the Birches.; I guess those Sons of Birches could not just celebrate the holiday by themselves. Kidding! On that sad day, the Dovers' young daughter Anna and the Birches' young daughter Eve went missing; a mysterious RV parked in front of the Birches' home might have had something to do with it. When the driver of the RV named Alex Jones is arrested as a possible suspect, Kellen goes all "cray cray" in order for the police not to release him even though there is not suffice evidence to book Jones. Jake Gyllenhaal co-stars as Detective Loki, who is not the real "loco" in the picture, but does get obsessed to solve the case and find the missing girls. Villenueve's direction was superb and some might argue that he was sadly missing in the list of Oscar- nominated film directors for 2013. Aaron Guzilowski's screenplay was pure, even though "Prisoners" sometimes got locked up with some clichés. It was great to see Jackman hide those big nails and singing voice, and transform himself into a character where he wore his emotions on his sleeve, and Hugh better believe that Jackman delivered the goods with his outstanding performance here. Gyllenhaal was also very good as Loki, as he continues his stellar acting career. Melissa Leo was stunning as the mysterious Aunt of Alex Jones; And speaking of Mr. Jones, Mr. Jones, Mr. Jones- Paul Dano delivered another effective cringe-worthy work as Alex Jones. Roger Deakins' cinematography of "Prisoners" was a scenic tour-de-force, even though I think that Deakins' "arrested development" of not getting the Oscars he deserves is a cinetragedy. OK, so I did write way too many pun-induced sentences for "Prisoners" after all; I guess that was a "hard cell" for you to believe I wouldn't. However, it is an easy sale for me to recommend the excellent "Prisoners". 
***** Excellent

Prisoners is a phenomenally acted, extremely tense, and very intelligent suspense thriller, even if it runs a little too long in its third act.

--FULL REVIEW TO COME--
Every scene offers a new piece to the puzzle, a truly excellent mystery film.

"Prisoners" is an effectively eerie, precisely written and directed film starring a fierce, if occasionally over-acting Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal in maybe his finest performance yet. "Prisoners" has the makings of a routine procedural but the performance and sharp script elevate the film to a much higher level. One of 2013's best films.
Could not have loved this movie more! If you liked Seven..this one is up your alley

There are some positives here, but mostly it's a thriller that goes on for a bit longer than necessary. There are many twists and turns, most of which work rather well. Some are a little more problematic, but not the most problematic aspect here.

The film's biggest problem is Hugh Jackman, who is simply unbelievable. The man goes from zero to psychotic vigilante almost instantly, and boy does it hurt the film BAD. There is no chance to sympathize with him, no chance to understand his plight, no chance to connect with him. The difficult part is whether this is the script's fault or Jackman's. Jackman certainly doesn't help by going completely bonkers in the first 15 minutes and staying bonkers until the end. Then again, the script doesn't give much of a chance for a transition. He goes from pious guy to straight-up lunatic really rapidly.

Everyone else is alright, though nobody really stands out. Still, better not drag it down than try to be a glory hog, I suppose. Deakins' cinematography, rightfully Oscar-nominated is astounding.

The film does overstay its welcome after a while, but it doesn't drag. It doesn't feel like a 2.5 hour film.
An intense thriller.

This is a drama with a very well acted Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal, but it went on just way too long. Overall not very enjoyable but it wasn't a total waste of time either, so... whatever I guess.

Really wanted to see that. Of course, that expectation opens the door for disappointment. The movie lived up to its promise of gloom, but I guess I did not expect more than two hours and the lame twists involved.

There is a foreign movie called Seven Days. It's a bit of torture porn that this movie almost seems to be based on. In that movie, a physician's daughter is killed and he takes and killer and tortures him for seven days. Then he delivers a brilliant line at the end. This is a bit like that movie but with all the ridiculous twists.

Didn't think the acting was horrible. Actually thought Dano was borderline brilliant as a complete oddball. Gyllenhaal's dark character was kind of likable but not real believable. Jackman is effective enough, and Howard, who has one of my favorite voices, doesn't do much.

If you make a mystery involving an RV and two missing girls, that should just about do it. To make it drag on past two hours and throw in some ridiculous kinks? I guess I don't see the point.
Good flick, would've been better with about 45 minutes shaved off.

Painful, brutal, and utterly dark, watching Prisoners is to endure an exercise in human suffering. Hugh Jackman's portrayal of a father pushed to desperation is truly haunting, his eyes burning with the need for vengeance. Opposite him is a solid performance by Gyllenhaal, who has proven to have a strong knack for this type of role. By the end of this film you are as likely to feel prisoner to its fate as the characters themselves; crisp direction and a stark but poignant script make this one of the better suspense films of 2013.

Prisoners was a great movie that seemed to get overlooked for some odd reason. Most people who didn't like it will say that it's too long or that it's too nihlistic. However, neither of those opinions seem all that valid to me. It's very much in the style of David Fincher in terms of style and pacing; it's extremely moody and slow boiling. The performances from Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal are the standouts as you'd expect, but everyone does a good job here. I enjoyed this movie not just for the strong narrative and characters, but the cinematography and attention to detail is amazing. The initial reaction to the movie as a whole can be a little jarring because it's so intense and dark, but it's definitely a soon to be cult classic once people get around to seeing it.

A dark suspenseful thriller that is not for the faint of heart--or stomach--"Prisoners" is an extremely gripping story that shows the darker sides of human nature, while still keeping a sense of hope and justice alive throughout.  Hugh Jackman shows his full strength as an actor as Keller, and flawlessly becomes a man desperate for answers who has some demons of his own.  Gyllenhaal's previous role as a cop in End of Watch may have helped him prepare for the sheer intensity of his role in Prisoners as a cold yet diligant detective who is married to the job, and refuses to give up until he unconvers the truth.  Prisoners takes two men with the same agenda and progressively shows the differences in methodology and mentality they go through to find two missing girls.  A very well written film that keeps you guessing, Prisoners will leave you wondering about the differences between right and wrong, and when/ if there can be any exceptions to that rule.

This movie poses some unnecessary twists, clues, and screaming, but it is essentially a mystery and crime-solving movie and any excess doesn't really damage the films enjoyment, even if it drags it to two-and-a-half-hours length.  Ultimately, the story is very well put together and the cast does a phenomenal job.

holy jesus... wanna watch actors act?? watch this. the intensity meter is at an all time high in this suspense/disturbing pic about verrrrryyyy relevant situations in today's socities. Look for an oscar nod or two for this one.

The mystery is very intruiging and kept me guessing into the end. You feel like you are watching a real situation unfold. The cinematography is perfect, the entire movie has a very dark tone with rain and snow everywhere. The shots are amazing, focusing on exactly what they should. It really is a masterpiece, even if it leaves you shocked. 90/100

If there's one thing that a viewer will get from watching this film it's that they'll never forget it.  Compacted with Hugh Jackman's terrifying performance and a darkly gripping tale, this film is a keeper.  It's not for the faint of heart; it contains scenes with cruel brutality and violence, and sure, it makes the viewer uneasy, but it doesn't stop them from wanting to see the ending.  Along with Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal and Paul Dano bring out a deeper and often creepier character than what was originally in the script.  You may not think of it at first, but this film also shows the problems with how America is dealing with it's war-on-terror, and if there's any hope left.

Prisoners is extremely suspenseful and equally disturbing. Canadian director Denis Villeneuve, whose last film was the equally spellbinding and disturbing Incendies, builds up the tension from the first frame and does not let up for the full 153 minutes of the movie. 

Aaron Guzikowski's script, though on the surface a child kidnapping thriller, bucks all Hollywood trends and, as well as being a taut thriller, poses serious moral issues. It also helps that the film has a first rate cast doing outstanding work: Hugh Jackman, Jake Gyllenhaal, Paul Dano, Terence Howard, Melissa Leo, Maria Bello and Viola Davis. Prisoners is not for the faint heated but is likely to feature strongly at this years oscars.

Engaging, methodological and powerful - but drags on a little too long. Great acting by the main cast, but lacks a little magic somewhere. Worth a watch, but just an inch shy from being a masterpiece.

Solid, clever plot.  Due to the complexity of it, I kept waiting for something to not fit in, for a hole in the script, but it never came.  Things that seemed random and unrelated (eg the priest) all had a purpose and made sense, in the end.

Good direction from Denis Villeneuve (who also directed the great drama Incendies).  Builds the suspense well, and keeps you engaged the whole time.  You would not know the movie is nearly 2 1/2 hours long it is so gripping and suspenseful and flows so well.

Solid performance from Hugh Jackman.  However, he is upstaged by Jake Gyllenhaal as the detective.  Fantastic performance by him.  He seemed to totally immerse himself in the role, down to nervous / sleep-deprived ticks.

Good support from Maria Bello, Terrence Howard, Viola Davis, Paul Dano and Melissa Leo.

I think the fact that he typically plays a great heel in every movie, worked to create a little conflict in our hearts as the situation worsens.   The movie itself looks great and builds tension very effectively. Ya you can figure out the bad guy pretty early on , but the movie is about more than just figuring out who took the girl.

Endure the slow middle part and you have a dark, gripping and solidly-acted thriller. Hugh Jackman and Jake Gyllenhaal carried the film together with its intriguing views on justice, morals and religion. The film had two distinct stories to tell. Terrance Howard was wasted whilst the ending unsurprising and poorly executed. There was some uncomfortable and carefully constructed moments which was great too watch. Alongside a well created eerie tone. I expected more from the storyline which is never good when its trying to dress up something so twisted for so long, it just didn't deliver as well as it could have done.

The story could be based on an actual case and THAT makes this story so compelling to me. The depth and emotional acting done by all of the cast, especially Jackman, Gyllenhaal, Dano, and Bello, drew me in and made me feel close to their characters. The real draw was how well they all interacted with each other; so perfect was the performances of Jackman, Bello, Howard, Davis, and Gyllenhaal, that one could feel how familiar they were to each other as if they really were from the area that the story took place. My biggest surprise was Leo's character when you realize the turn of events that the story has to offer. If not for the Academy's apparent disregard for such a genre, I would suggest these people for Oscar nomination.

A stunning achievement with a stellar cast.  Two families find their comfortable middle class worlds ripped apart when both of their young daughters disappear. rt there with Mud, Passion, The East, and Place Beyond the Pines as one of the years best. At least out of the 70 or so I've seen so far. Yet to see Gravity and 12 years a Slave though.

Of all the films that have come out this year, Prisoners is by far one of the most underrated. It is one of the most unpleasant yet fascinating morality tale. It is not only one of the best films of the year, but one of the few films that went beyond my expectations. 

During one raining afternoon, two young girls are kidnapped, leaving the two families devastated. The two fathers, played by Hugh Jackman and Terrence Howard are dealing with the stress of their families when an seemingly obvious suspect, played by Paul Dano, seems to have gone missing. Though it turns out Jackman's character has kidnapped him in order to torture him for information. Meanwhile detective Loki, played by Jake Gyllenhaal, suspects there is much more to this case than meets the eye.

Lets start by talking about the best aspect of the film: the acting. This is by far one of the most well acted films of the year. Howard, Maria Bello, Viola Davis are all amazing and convincing in their roles, making the kidnapping scenario feel all the more real. Gyllenhaal is also pretty damn good playing the brilliant but flawed cop. But by the best performance in the entire film, that should have earned an Oscar nod, is Hugh Jackman. I've always been a fan of him, but this is one of his best roles. He always walks the fine line between sympathetic father and brutal extremist. It is much harder to find the balance between these two personalities, but Jackman is wonderful. 

While the story is a little straightforward and very reminiscent of Gone Baby Gone, I certainly loved the dark tone and moral and ethical questions raised in this film. How far would go to save your family? What if you're wrong? What if you killed an innocent man? These are some of the questions raised, but never fully answered, leaving it up to the audience to decide. That and how beautiful this movie is shot. For a film so dark, both thematically and visually, the cinematography is amazing. It was one of the few things the Academy got right this year by nominating it for Best Cinematography. 

If I had one grip with the film, it is the twist. It is not bad by any means, and it is very shocking. But my problem is with the motivation of the villain. It feels a little cliched while the rest of the film was so realistic. That and some of the twists get a little too complicated. 

It is still one of the best films of the year, though I would not recommend for everyone, especially for parents, given how dark and realistic it is. Still, the overall picture is worth a few flaws.

***1/2 (out of 4)

Produced by busy bee actor Mark Wahlberg and helmed by acclaimed Canadian director Denis Villeneuve, Prisoners is the type of vehicle that is perfect for fall movie going season. It was filmed in Georgia (which I believe, was made to look like a drab part of Pennsylvania), takes place during Thanksgiving, and harbors a non-stop sense of doom and gloom from its opening frame (I think the sun shined maybe once during the entire 2 and a half hour running time). Listen, I'm not going to sugarcoat it for you, this picture is long, feels long, and it really takes its time. Villeneuve uses old school filming techniques and doesn't project anything flashy at all. The story, when it's all said and done however, is somewhat conventional. Therefore, I think it was necessary for the events to be drawn out and dragged through the muck a little. Based on an initial viewing, I realized that Prisoners would have felt like a TV movie and/or a Law and Order episode if the running time was trimmed to say, an hour and a half. Thankfully, it comes off as an extended director's cut (I'm not the only critic that felt this way) and that to a fault, is what makes the flick work. Watching it, I was reminded of a David Fincher film (without Fincher's signature style though) and not just because it starred staggeringly disciplined actor Jake Gyllenhaal. Prisoners is basically a mild spawn of Fincher's Se7en and Zodiac. It's not quite as effectively creepy as those films, but it's definitely good enough to recommend.  

Part kidnapping movie, part police detective character study, and part fatherly vigilante escapade, Prisoners tells the story of two families (neighbors from across the street) who get together on Thanksgiving day. The Birch's (Franklin Birch played by Terrence Howard and Nancy Birch played by Viola Davis who barely registers here) and the Dover's (Hugh Jackman and Maria Bello as Keller and Grace Dover) have a relaxing, calming holiday until their respective daughters wander off and go missing. This then gets the attention of a socially inept area detective (Mr. Loki played with vigor by Jake Gyllenhaal) who garners almost complete control over handling the missing person's case. As days go by and a potential suspect who might've taken the children gets bounced free, Jackman's angry, frustrated character eventually decides to take the law into his own hands. As the film slowly creeps toward its conclusion, you get small twists and turns (as well as slightly minimal character revelations). You also get to see how important drawing mazes are when it comes to character motivation (I've seen all kinds of thrillers and this plot point was a first for me). 

On the acting front, one thing to notice when viewing Prisoners, is how it pushes aside the other performers in the main cast (Oscar nominees like Viola Davis and Terrence Howard) and puts its main focus on Jackman. Now I'm not saying that Hugh Jackman is a mediocre actor. I just don't think he has the fiery chops to take on such a serious, dramatic role. His fault lies in the extreme overacting and preening to the audience. He seems to be saying, "hey look at me, I should be nominated for an Oscar!" With all the focus on him, the other player's roles become seriously underdeveloped. It gets to the point where you hardly see them anymore. Using little of no background music, there are a lot of carefully set up scenes in Prisoners. To a fault, Jackman appears in almost all of them. Jake Gyllenhaal (Detective Loki), the only other actor receiving top billing, takes up almost as much of the shared time. The difference with Gyllenhaal is that he quietly out acts his co-star. His minutes on screen are underplayed but they feel more genuine, more studied (Gyllenhaal's character's facial ticks like eye blinking were a nice touch), and generally more effective. He seems born to play his role. Jackman on the other hand, has one persuasive agent (he probably needs to stick to his strengths which are the X-Men movies).  

As a fall release that feels as if it's a journey or a metaphoric expedition, Prisoners has a teaser of an ending that may leave viewers holding their hands in the air. The over length may also be a factor when it comes to their varied attention spans. I however, found this exercise mildly absorbing and it was able to keep me interested. You may find the opening ten minutes a little muddled and weak in terms of set up, but after that, this exercise will place you in its grip (not too tightly) and not let go. Like I said earlier, Prisoners makes its case for being serviceable because it rides the wave of other crime dramas filling the screen with gloomy, overcast, and rain-drenched sequences. While watching it, you can almost sense that it does hold back just a little. This film doesn't take too many risks and it may not haunt you like it should (Villeneuve's direction is overly careful). But hey, it still gets by though mainly because of said look and Gyllenhaal's icy magnitude. All in all, if you like crime thrillers that take their time and don't try to jerk you around with the camera, Prisoners might just set you "free."
